head_text.subj: CREDITS OVER PHOTOS IN AN ALBUM

text: The photos include a sepia-tone portrait of an Italian  immigrant family... a b&w snapshot of ROBERTA, a nine-yea old girl playing violin in front of a refrigerator (1950) ...Roberta and her dashing Italian father, hand-carving a wooden music stand... a b&w snapshot of Roberta in a comm dress... Roberta at 15, playing violin in front of the sa refrigerator, eyes on the music stand... ...a color photo of two cute blonde little boys building sandcastle on a beach... a color photo of a groom in a wh naval uniform and his pretty bride, (Roberta at 25), her  hand over his as they cut their wedding cake with a sword ...a color photo of Roberta and her husband Greek dancing with another couple at an outdoor taverna. Roberta's husb and the other man's sexy wife are exchanging a slight smi HOLD ON THIS LAST PHOTO as we now see the ALBUM open on t floor of a bedroom, as if it's been tossed. We are:
Wake up, Roberta!
We hear the sound of KNOCKING as the CAMERA PANS a small, darkened guest room. A few streaks of daylight filter thr Venetian blinds.
Come on, Bert -- get out of bed!
The CAMERA finds a WOMAN lying face down on a twin bed, t wavy hair sprawled across her shoulders.
Please, Bert -- you need to get out  of that bed.
The KNOCKING continues, and she puts the pillow over the of her head.

The WOMAN -- ROBERTA GUASPARI-DEMETRAS (38) -- retrieves photo album from the floor, looks at a photo and removes She's a beautiful woman with large, expressive eyes, but  right now she looks like hell. She stares at the photo -- it's the two couples dancing. A quick glimpse of hurt on face, then her jaw tightens and she rips the picture in h There's muffled talking outside the door, and then two yo boys' voices.
Can you come out now, Mommy? Please?
She puts the half with her and her husband on the dresser then tears the woman off the other half and rips her into pieces.
Mommy, Nick broke my crayon!
Well, Lexi hit me and he almost  broke... he almost broke my ear!

O.S. arguing "I DID NOT!" "YES YOU DID!" "LIAR!" etc. As that one action siphoned all her energy, Roberta returns bed, gets into fetal position, and stares at a point beyo the wall, ignoring the O.S. voices.
Hear that? Your boys need you.

ASSUNTA GUASPARI (58), Roberta's slender, tired Italian- American mother, stands in the doorway of a well-tended  working-class home, addressing a young NAVAL OFFICER who  holds a lengthy delivery inventory. It's a gray day with  ominous storm clouds. Late 70's CARS are parked on the st
But I have no room for this!
I'm sorry, M'am. We have orders to  deliver these.
Assunta looks beyond the man, dismayed.

Large wooden CRATES cover her front lawn, and TWO MOVERS  plant down another. They hurry back to the TRUCK, grabbin the next crate too quickly this time. It slips from their hands, CRASHES to the ground and splinters open. Several  VIOLIN CASES spill out. The crate looks like it holds a w lot more.
Instantly a second-story window is flung open, and Robert sticks her head out, a hundred times more energized than  we've seen her so far.
Watch it, you idiots! Be careful  with those!
The men scramble to pick them up. Assunta looks at all th violins, then up at Roberta.
Why so many?
Roberta disappears inside and slams the window shut.

The living room is filled with boxes shipped from Greece, labelled by the U.S. NAVY. And on the floor, in the middl of the boxes, are FIFTY VIOLIN CASES of various sizes, al with Greek and U.S. NAVY labels. NICK (7) and LEXI (5) cl over the boxes as if they were giant blocks.
(calling) Mommy, which box has our toys?
ROBERTA'S on the phone, yelling at someone. She's still i the same ratty nightgown.
Look, I know he's there, so quit  lying to me!... Then check under  Lana Holden -- Mrs. Lana Holden...  Fine. Just tell Lieutenant Demetras  that his wife called and --
ASSUNTA grabs the phone from her hand and hangs it up.
Ma!
No. I want you to listen to me. You  can't keep doing this to yourself --  or to the boys. They need their mother  now. You're a beautiful, talented  woman and you have your whole life  ahead of you.
If I'm so beautiful and talented,  why did Charles leave me?
Because Charles is a big jerk. (beat) Now get dressed.
She exits, leaving Roberta to mull over her words.

Coffee is brewing and homemade cinnamon rolls are cooling a rack. We recognize the kitchen from the home movie foot As Assunta clears the boys' breakfast dishes from the tab Roberta enters. She's dressed, but hasn't put on makeup o done much with her hair. It's a start.
You really think Charles is a jerk?
From the day you married him.
Why didn't you say something?
Since when do you listen to me?
Roberta half-smiles, pours herself some coffee, then sits down at the table.
(sighs, then) What am I gonna do?
First, you eat breakfast. Second,  you go out and get a job -- any job.  Your boys, god-bless-em, are good  eaters -- but I can't afford it.
Mama, he's gonna get tired of her --  you'll see.
Assunta's face shows she's doubtful about this.
Well in the meantime, get a job.

Roberta is behind the counter, meticulously wrapping a pr with ribbons, bows and stickers. At one point she even un a ribbon and redoes it because it's not perfect. She look pretty, but she's dressed conservatively, like a navy  housewife. There's only one other clerk wrapping gifts an long line of impatient customers. A male SUPERVISOR appea behind Roberta.
Just wrap. You're not Picasso.
He exits, and Roberta quickly tries to finish her task.
Picasso would probably put the bows  on the back of the box.
Roberta looks up to find BRIAN TURNER (40), a handsome, s guy with longish hair and a beat-up leather jacket.
Brian Turner?
Hello, Roberta.
I thought you moved away.
I did. I'm in town for my Mom's  birthday.
He holds out his hand. Roberta misunderstands the gesture and tries to shake his hand.
No -- that's her gift.
(embarrassed) Oh! Sorry.
Roberta hands him the gift she's been wrapping.
It looks very pretty.
Thank you. (beat) I heard you had a book published. I  didn't read it but...
That's O.K. My parents didn't read  it either. It looks good on their  coffee table, though.
Roberta smiles.
So what are you doing here? I thought  you'd be in Carnegie Hall by now.
HOLD ON ROBERTA as she takes this in.
Roberta sits opposite Brian. Her lunch is untouched.
My college professors said it was  too late -- I hadn't had enough  training to be a concert violinist.  So I got a teaching degree instead.
I'll bet you're a great teacher.

I think I am. It's just that... (sighs) See, every time I'd get started  somewhere, Charles would be  transferred... then I had my kids  and took time off to raise them...  and then when I decided to teach  again, no one would hire me 'cause  you can't count on a navy wife to  stick around. I finally decided I'd  start my own program -- Charles gave  me the money and I bought fifty  violins from this little Greek shop --  got started at a private school and  then...
Your husband ran off with your best  friend.
A beat.

She wasn't my "best" friend. She was  a friend. (beat) Charles is the last person you'd  think would cheat on me -- he never  broke a rule... (a few beats) I wake up one night -- it's like one  in the morning -- and he's not in  bed. I go outside and our neighbor --  this old Greek guy -- is sitting out  there, smoking a cigar, so I ask if  he's seen my husband. "He's taking a  walk with the other officer's wife,"  he says. "He takes a walk every night  with the other officer's wife."
A beat as she gets lost in the memory. She takes a bite o french fry.
God, these are cold.
So you're just gonna wrap presents  and wait for him to come back?
You sound like my mother.
That's not very sexy.
Are you trying to be sexy or be my  friend?
A little of both.
Roberta smiles, blushing a bit. Brian looks at her, getti an idea.

You know, I know this really cool  lady who runs this elementary school --  I wrote a piece on her. It's a public  school, but it's alternative -- she  might be able to create some kind of  gig for you. Let me give her a call.
Great!
(takes his last bite  of sandwich) If she hires you, though, you have  to be willing to relocate.
Where is it?

A SALSA SONG PLAYS OVER as we see stores with Spanish nam and signs; Black and Latino elementary school children wa home from school; some burned-out buildings; Black and La teens playing basketball on a cement court; Spanish graff on walls; elderly women buying fruit at a produce stand. PULL BACK TO REVEAL this is the POV of Roberta from the b seat of a cab. The SALSA SONG plays on the cab's radio.  Roberta looks scared shitless. Suddenly, two YOUNG MEN flash down the middle of the stre dart IN FRONT of the cab and the driver SLAMS on the brak jerking Roberta forward.
Welcome to East Harlem.

JANET WILLIAMS, a Black woman (40's) with a kind face, si behind her desk and looks at Roberta's resume. A sign on desk indicates that she's the DIRECTOR. Also on the desk a FRAMED PICTURE of Janet, her husband, daughter (14), an son (12). Roberta sits nervously in the chair opposite he

(looking at resume) Aside from half a term in a private  school -- in Greece -- and a year  teaching chorus in Hawaii -- ten  years ago -- it doesn't look like  you've had any other teaching  experience.
Well, not traditional teaching  experience. I've been doing private  lessons...
Janet looks for this on the resume.
It's not on there... I taught my  sons.
Janet smiles politely.

I'd like to help you, Mrs. Demetras.  Brian spoke highly of you and I told  him I'd consider starting a violin  class... But without the proper  qualifications, and without any  experience in an inner city school...
Roberta nods, defeated.
I'm very sorry.
Roberta stands outside Janet's office, dejectedly watchin the children noisily running through the hall.
Roberta knocks on Janet's door.
Yes?

As Roberta opens the door, we see that Nick and Lexi are  with her. All three have violins. INSIDE, Janet's in  conversation with DENNIS RAUSCH (38), an uptight man with tie that doesn't match his suit jacket. He's showing Jane large scheduling chart.
I'm sorry to interrupt, but I wanted  you to meet my sons -- Nick, Lexi...
They enter.
Janet smiles at the boys, but clearly thinks Roberta's a  little off. Roberta holds her hand out to Dennis.
Roberta Guaspari-Demetras.
Dennis shakes her hand, regarding her warily.
This is Dennis Rausch, our music  teacher and program coordinator. (beat) Mrs. Demetras, didn't I make things  clear yesterday?
If I could just show you something --  it'll only take a minute.
Before Janet can answer, Roberta and the kids quickly tak out their violins and get into position. Janet and Dennis exchange a look.
Are we having a talent show? I should  have brought my tap shoes.

Roberta ignores the jab, then nods to the boys. The three them begin an incredibly impressive violin trio, playing ETUDE in three-part harmony. For the first measures, Jane still annoyed by the intrusion, but she's quickly won ove Dennis watches impassively. Roberta and the boys finish their piece; Janet applauds a Dennis joins in to be polite. The three take bows. A beat
Will you hire her now?
Janet laughs, then gestures for them to sit.
How long have you boys been playing?
Since I was three.
(contemplates, then) Maybe since I was three and a half.
Your mom must be a good teacher.
(shrugs) She's O.K.
Roberta gives Nick a look, but Janet smiles.
(to Roberta) If you could teach our students to  play like that, I'd be thrilled, but --
I can. Any child can learn the violin.
Assuming they had the discipline.
I'll teach them to have discipline.
A lot of our parents are struggling  to feed their kids and pay the rent --  they don't have time to help them  learn violin.
They don't have to. If they can help,  great -- but these kids will be  committed. They'll practice on their  own, they'll help each other in the  classroom --
Dennis laughs. Roberta looks at him, a bit miffed.
(with an edge) I think I know these students, Miss  Demetras. Their attention span doesn't  go past do-re-mi. Maybe on a good  day, I can get them to "fa."
You're underestimating them. They  can play as well as any other kids.
That I'd like to see.
You will.
A beat. Janet observes the tension, then turns to Roberta
(to Roberta) For now I'll put you down as a sub,  but I have to warn you -- even if it  works out, the Board may not let me  create a permanent position for you.
That's O.K. I'll worry about that  later. (with a grateful look) Thank you.
We see relief -- and fear -- in Roberta's face.
(to Janet) Well, I've already planned out the  whole term, and I can tell you right  now, there's no room for this!  Besides, where you gonna find money  for violins?
You need violins?
In a noisy music room with bad acoustics, Roberta tries t take control of fifty kids, third through fifth-graders, are in a state of manic excitement over the FIFTY VIOLIN  CASES on the floor.
(gently) Please do not open the cases, O.K.?
They ignore her.
Look, can everyone just settle down  and listen to me -- please?
ANGLE - Three girls open their cases.
(starting to lose it) Keep them closed! Please.
ANGLE - Two boys open their cases.
(to the boys) Did you hear what I just said?
ANGLE - Three kids are using the violin cases as pretend  machine guns -- and shooting each other.
Put those down, please!
ANGLE - A boy and a girl are having a "sword fight" with  their bows.
(to the fencers) Don't do that! Put the bows back in  the cases -- right now!
There's the SOUND of violin strings being plucked.
Who's plucking?
Roberta wheels around to find a girl plucking her violin  like a banjo, and doing a little dance. This is LUCY, a s Puerto Rican girl in perpetual motion.
What have I been saying? Put that  away! Back in the case!
Roberta takes a breath. The kids settle down a bit.
O.K. Thank you. That's much better. (takes another breath) I'll be dividing you into five  classes, but for today --
ANGLE - A boy plays "bongos" on his violin case.
O.K. -- that's it! You! Stand up!
The bongo player stands.
You will be the first student who  will NOT be in my violin class. Out!
The child looks stunned.
I said OUT!
With a sheepish expression, he exits. The room is finally quiet -- and Roberta's amazed that something worked. She  puffs up a little bit, enjoying the feeling of control.
Who else would like to be kicked out  of my class?
The students stare at her, afraid of her now. DE SEAN, a  small but tough Black boy, raises his hand.
Are you raising your hand because  you want to be kicked out?
Yeah.
Why?
I don't wanna learn no stupid violin.  It's for wimps.
Who told you that?
I just know.
What's your name?
De Sean.
Well, De Sean -- you haven't given  me a good enough reason, so you're  staying.
She looks around the room.
Anyone else?
Silence.

In front of the class, Roberta helps NAEEM, a graceful Bl boy, hold the violin. He has a serious expression and a s on his left cheek. Roberta controls the bow and fingerboa but it appears that the boy is playing music. He smiles.
Hey, I play pretty good.
Roberta laughs.
(to Naeem) See how easy it is? (to the class) Maybe in the spring, we could have a  big concert for your families and  for the whole school. (to the boy) What's your name?
Naeem.
Roberta writes in a notebook and we see that she's measur for violin sizes.

(to class) If you listen to me and do exactly  what I say, you're gonna sound  beautiful at the concert and you're  gonna be so proud of yourselves. (to Naeem) Good, Naeem. Your hand's staying  soft. (to the class) But if you don't listen to me, you'll  sound so bad that your own parents  will feel sick when they hear you.  They might even throw up.
ON THE KIDS, not used to a teacher speaking like that.

A funky apartment on the Upper West Side. Nick and Lexi a both asleep in sleeping bags on top of a futon on the flo their suitcases nearby. Brian tiptoes past them, carrying two glasses of champagne. He knocks on his office door.
Come in.

Roberta's in a bathrobe and nightgown, some rollers in he hair. She's tidying up her suitcase, etc., next to an old couch that's been made up as a bed. Leftist political boo line a shelf above Brian's desk, including copies of his  own, TO HELL AND BACK: INTERVIEWS WITH VIETNAM VETS by BR TURNER. His desk is covered with files and books pertaini to MIGRANT WORKERS. Brian enters.
(referring to champagne) What's this?
It's a toast. (giving her a glass,  holding his up) To Roberta, who's made it through  her first week.
They clink glasses and drink.
I don't know, Brian. I'm hanging on  by a thread there. Out of fifty kids,  maybe six are listening to me.
Look at the progress. Didn't you say  no one was listening to you on Monday?
Roberta laughs.
I really appreciate all you've done  for us. And I promise -- this weekend  I'll start looking for a place.
There's no rush.
No, we've put you out enough. You're  supposed to be writing, not  babysitting for us. (crosses to his desk,  flips through his  Vietnam book) I've started your book. It's very  powerful.
Thank you.
Brian comes up behind her and starts to kiss her neck.  Roberta's scared -- so she keeps talking, as if it's not  really happening.
So what made you choose migrant  workers for your next book? I mean,  how do you know what to write about?
(kissing her neck) I follow my gut, pay attention to  what I'm being drawn to...
Roberta's aroused, in spite of herself. She turns around faces him.
What are you doing?
I've been waiting to do that since  Mr. Baines' orchestra class.
You didn't even notice me!
Sure I did. You used to ignore me  and it drove me wild.
You had at least five different  girlfriends.
It didn't mean I had the one I wanted.
He gives her a flirtatious smile, then takes out one of h rollers.
You're not a navy wife anymore...
He moves to takes out another roller and Roberta stops hi
Yes I am... legally.
And is it a navy requirement that  you dress like it's the 1950's?
I do not!
(goading her) Who did you vote for in the last  election?
What does that have to do with  anything?
Tell me.
(hesitates, then) I don't know. Charles filled out my  absentee ballot.
Oh my God -- it's even worse than I  thought! (touching her hair) Is this the same Roberta who got the  orchestra to strike until they gave  us new uniforms?
She laughs wistfully, then looks a little sad.
That Roberta's not around anymore.
He pulls her towards him by the belt to her robe.
I don't believe that.
They kiss and it heats up quickly. Roberta pulls back.
I shouldn't.
Because?
The boys --
They're sleeping.
I know, but... I'm still married.
And what's your husband doing right  now?
A few beats, and she moves towards him.
Sun streams into the room as Roberta awakens in Brian's b a look of afterglow on her face. She suddenly remembers w she is, and quickly looks at the clock.
Oh shit -- the boys.
They're still sleeping.
She turns, relieved, until she sees that Brian's packing suitcase.
Where are you going?
Texas.
He dashes out. Roberta sits up, rattled by this news.
Brian excitedly gathers papers and files scattered around his electric typewriter.
What's in Texas?
He turns to see Roberta in the doorway.
Farm workers. I just got the call --  it came through -- my research grant!  It came through! Isn't that great?
Today?
He places items into a carry-on bag, packing at a rapid c In contrast, Roberta seems to be moving in slow motion.
I've got a few families lined up  there, some in California --
How long will you be gone?
Two, three months.
What?
Brian throws toiletries into a plastic bag. Roberta enter
I thought... I just thought you were  gonna be around. And then last night --
He stops what he's doing and looks at her.
Whoa. Roberta -- last night was great  but did you think I was gonna marry  you in the morning?
No! Of course not.
We see in her face that part of her did think that.
It's just that... we just got here  and we're barely... I don't even  know where to buy groceries.
Brian softens as he sees how vulnerable she is. He takes in his arms.
You're gonna be fine. You have a  job, a place to stay, your kids have  a school to go to -- and there's a  D'Agostino's around the corner.
She attempts a smile.
Congratulations.
He kisses her forehead, then exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA, look hurt and frightened.

Roberta rosins her bow, standing in front of ten kids --  third through fifth-grade -- who sit on the floor next to their violin cases. The kids are Black and Latino, with a couple of white faces. They're all talking and ignoring  Roberta except for NAEEM and GUADALUPE, a petite Mexican  girl with a long dark braid. [NOTE: We'll see other violi students from time to time, but this is the class we'll f for Roberta's first year]
And what am I doing now?
Rosining the bow.
Good. And what am I doing when I  turn this little screw? (raising her voice) Everyone stop talking. Right now!
The kids quiet down. Only Naeem raises his hand.
Naeem?
Tightening the horse hair.
(touches the heel of  the bow) And what do we call this?
Again, only Naeem raises his hand. Roberta sees him but t to DE SEAN, who's talking to his neighbor.
De Sean?
Yeah?
What do we call this?
I don't know.
Why not?
I wasn't here.
Yes you were but you weren't paying  attention! Do you want people to  think you're stupid?
This makes De Sean blush -- and it pisses him off.
All right, Naeem -- tell them.
It's called the frog.
Some kids giggle and joke about this. Roberta points to t scroll of the violin.
Anyone remember what this is?
LUCY, the fidgety girl, snaps her fingers.
Lucy! Do you like people snapping  their fingers when you're talking?
Yeah!
The kids laugh. Roberta doesn't. She points to the scroll
What is this called?
The jeri curl?
Roberta laughs, even though she's trying to be tough.

Dennis's twenty students play recorder in rows of attache theatre-style seats. Dennis sits at his desk, a METRONOME ticking, and apathetically leads them in scales, using a pen as a baton. He keeps one eye on a stack of quizzes th he's marking, stopping to circle mistakes with the pen.
C-C-C-C, D-D-D-D, E-E-E-E...
ANGLE - Roberta stands in the hallway at the open door,  dismayed by Dennis' uninspired teaching. She enters and  crosses to Dennis, speaking quietly to him.
Excuse me -- sorry to interrupt --
The students immediately start to chatter.
No talking!
He looks back at Roberta, annoyed by her intrusion.
I'm supposed to take kids out of  Miss Cooper's classroom for my ten  o'clock class -- there's nobody there.
Miss Cooper's students have phys ed  on Tuesdays.
But you scheduled them for violin.
You must have read the schedule wrong.
(trying to remain  polite) I don't think so.
Well, I can't solve this problem for  you right now. (nods to his class) I'm trying to teach.
So am I.
She exits.
Lexi and Nick are in Brian's bed. Roberta's tucking in Le he holds a toy truck with Greek writing on it.
Can I bring a puppy for show and  tell tomorrow?
Honey, we don't have a puppy.
Daddy said we could get one when we  moved back to America.
Roberta looks at Nick, then turns back to Lexi.
How about your truck? I'll bet you're  the only one in school with a truck  from Greece.
When's Daddy coming back?
Roberta turns to Nick and tucks him in.
Well, he's still on his tour, so  we'll just have to see but... It  shouldn't be too much longer.
Is he gonna live with us and Brian?
No, honey. We're just staying at  Brian's house for a little while.
She turns back to Nick who looks worried. She kisses him.
Good night, sweetie.
She kisses Lexi, then reaches to turn off the lamp.
No! Leave it on.
Roberta nods, smiles at her sons, and exits.
Nine children stand, violins under their right arms, bows hanging down from their right hands, and try to position  their feet as Roberta addresses them.
Now take the right foot and put it  on a tile. Good. Now with the other  foot take a tiny step forward and  put it on a line. Try to make a box  with your feet --
She walks over to BENJAMIN, a white boy with glasses, and corrects his feet. She sees Lucy dancing in place.
Lucy! Would you like to leave the  class right now?
Lucy nods, giggling. Roberta walks down the row of studen
You should feel very strong -- so  strong and balanced that if I wanted  to knock you over I couldn't.
She crosses to TANISHA, a sweet-natured Black girl with h hair in tiny braids, and gently pushes her belly.
You see? If you're standing strong,  I can't even push you.
Roberta turns to De Sean, who's talking to JAMES, a pudgy Black/Puerto Rican boy.
De Sean! James! Quiet! (as she crosses to  another student) Does anyone know where Naeem is?
I saw him this morning but he's not  here.
Yes, I know he's not here -- that's  why I'm asking.
She gently pushes Guadalupe's belly. The girl stumbles ba
See how I pushed you? It means your  feet aren't centered.
Guadalupe tries to correct her feet. Roberta bends down t help and sees that the little girl wears LEG BRACES under her pants. Roberta stands and gestures to one of the boys
Can you bring over a chair? (to Guadalupe) It's probably better for you to sit.
The boy brings the chair. Guadalupe sits, embarrassed.
Roberta walks through a school yard filled with kids and  parents picking them up. She sees Naeem and crosses to hi
Where were you today, Naeem?
I can't be in violin class anymore.
Why not?
My mother won't let me.
What?
NAEEM'S MOTHER, MRS. ADISA, steps INTO FRAME. She's an  attractive Black woman in a dress and head scarf made of  African fabric.
My son's got more important things  to do than learn dead white men's  music.
They're gonna learn "Twinkle Twinkle  Little Star"!
How many Black classical composers  can you name? How many Black classical  violinists do you know?
That doesn't mean it's the way it  should be. Naeem's learning to play  music -- and that makes him feel  good about himself. Why should it  matter who wrote it?
Please, Mom? Can't I be in the class?
Mrs. Adisa puts a protective arm around her son, then  addresses Roberta.
Look. I've seen this before. You  white women come up here and think  you can rescue our poor inner city  children who never asked to be rescued  in the first place. No thank you.
She walks off with Naeem. He glances back at Roberta, the turns away quickly. Roberta watches after them.

Roberta attempts to read Brian's book, To Hell and Back:  Interviews with Vietnam Vets, but she's distracted. She  glances at her purse, then back to the book. She puts the book down and dials the phone.
Brian Turner's room, please.

While she waits, she looks at Brian's picture on the book jacket. There's no answer and she hangs up. She starts to straighten the already clean room, then gets her purse, t out her wallet, and opens it to the plastic covered pictu
Charles in uniform; a studio shot of the boys when they w 3 and 1; the whole family posed on the terrace of their h in Greece, a view of the ocean behind them.
She's really depressed herself now.
ALICE CROWLEY (50's), a no-nonsense Black teacher, shows fifth-graders a globe. She doesn't turn as Roberta enters and crosses to her. In the b.g. we see ROBERTA'S STUDENTS waiting in THE HALL.
And which ocean is this?
Kids simultaneously yell out "ATLANTIC" and "PACIFIC."
Excuse me... I'm here for the violin  students.
(icy) You're late.
Just a couple of minutes -- I'm sorry.
They're having a lesson now.
But this is when they have violin  class!
That's not my problem.
Roberta's reluctant to argue in front of the kids; she ex
Lots of noise and chaos as kids run wild during lunch rec Janet rushes through the throngs while Roberta tries to k up.
I thought all the teachers agreed to  this.
In theory. (to a student) Adam! I want you in my office right  after lunch, you understand?
What'd I do?
Think about it! (to Roberta) Whenever you pull kids out, it's a  disruption, plus it's extra work for  the teacher 'cause they have to fill  the kids in on what they missed.  Some teachers resent it.
Well, can't you talk to them?
Janet stops walking and pulls a box cutter out of her poc
I took this off a second-grader this  morning. I'll help you Roberta --  but I can't hold your hand here.
Janet starts to walk away, then turns.
A word of advice? When you're picking  up your students, go to Alice's  classroom first.
Roberta stands there as Janet walks on ahead.
The nine children hold their violins in position as Rober addresses them.
So pretend you're driving a car and  I'm the policeman and I say STOP!  Thumb up, fingers straight up, flat  palm. Now you be policemen, but turn  your hand and make it say stop to  yourself.
ON THE CHILDREN, attempting this. She walks around and he
(to himself) You're under arrest.
Some kids crack up and start joking and chatting.

Knock it off, De Sean! (to all) If you kids can't take this seriously,  I don't want you here. I'm teaching  you a difficult instrument because I  respect you and have faith that you  can learn it. But none of that matters  if you don't have respect for  yourself.
Some of the children think about what she's saying. A cou uncomfortable with the intensity, hold back giggles.
Now turn your wrist so it's flat  against the fingerboard, and that's  how you'll set up your hand...
Roberta sees Guadalupe struggling.
Guadalupe! You've got the violin in  the wrong hand! How did that happen?
Embarrassed, Guadalupe corrects her position.

At the small kitchen table, Nick does homework and Lexi p stickers in a sticker book. Roberta's cooking dinner; she grabs a potholder and checks on a bubbling lasagna in the oven. The PHONE RINGS and she answers it.
Hello?
Hello, Bobbi.
Her face falls as she hears the voice. She holds onto the counter to steady herself.
Where are you?
(calm, detached) I'm back in the States. I'm at my  parents.
Roberta closes the oven and gathers her courage.
Are you still with her?
A beat.
No.
We watch Roberta's body collapse into a sense of overwhel relief. FOLLOW HER as she steps into THE HALLWAY, then  stretches the phone into:
She half-closes the door, leans against the sink and star to cry.

(through tears) We've missed you so much, Charles.  The boys... they can't wait for you  to come home... I know we'll have a  lot to work out and it won't be easy  right away, but we're gonna get  through this, you know? We're a family  and we belong together and --
(more emotive than  before) Bobbi -- stop, O.K.? Just stop.
Roberta looks as if she's been slapped. A beat.
I want a divorce.
What?
Silence.
But you said... you and Lana... you  said it was over.
It is. (beat) It's over between us too, Bobbi.
HOLD ON ROBERTA, devastated. ANGLE on NICK, watching her  through the door.
Brian's on the phone with Roberta. He's in a t-shirt and  sweats, and his papers are scattered on the bed.
He wouldn't even talk about it! No  explanations, no discussion...
Roberta in Brian's living room. She's extremely agitated her eyes are puffy from crying.
I can't believe you were still holding  out hope. The guy hasn't called you  or the kids in three months -- I  thought you'd moved on.
I never said that.
No? Maybe not with words.
This embarrasses her, then pisses her off.
You know what? I shouldn't have called  you. This was a mistake.
No, no -- I'm sorry. Look, I know it  hurts, but you're gonna get through  this, Roberta -- you will.
I'm moving back to my Mom's.
What? You're gonna quit teaching in  the middle of the term?
I don't fit in there -- I'm not making  any progress with the kids...
What are you gonna tell Janet --  your husband left you and nothing  else matters?
I don't know yet.
Roberta lies awake on the futon, heartbroken.
Roberta stands and watches Nick and Lexi sleep. She lies  down beside them and closes her eyes.
Roberta walks through crowds of kids towards Janet who's the middle of confronting a boy student. Janet holds a FI DOLLAR BILL. Roberta hangs back and waits for a chance to speak.
My mother gave it to me.
Why would she give you fifty dollars?
To buy breakfast.
Janet gives him a stern look.
Do you know how hard your mother  works? Do you think it's right for  you steal from her?
I didn't!
Well let's go call her right now and  ask her.
As Janet turns to walk off, Roberta crosses to her.
I need to speak to you. It's  important.
It'll have to wait. (to the boy) Come on. In my office.
Roberta watches as Janet dashes off with the boy in tow.
Guadalupe sits on a chair in the empty room, struggling t set up her violin. Roberta enters, surprised to see her.
Guadalupe? What are you doing here?
I can't get the stop sign.
Honey, your teacher's probably looking  for you.
Guadalupe sighs, then hands Roberta the violin.
I can't come anymore. It's too hard.
The violin is hard for everyone.
But everyone else is better than me.  I'll always be slow.
Roberta looks at her sadly and puts the violin in its cas
Did you ever hear of Itzhak Perlman?
No.
He's one of the greatest violinists  in the world, and he has problems  with his legs too. He walks with two  canes -- but he still makes the most  beautiful music.
And he sits down when he plays?
He has to.
Guadalupe takes this in.
He was your student?
Roberta laughs.
No. But if he was, I'd tell him the  same thing I'm telling you. You  shouldn't quit something just because  it's hard.
But I can't stand strong.
Standing strong doesn't only mean  using your legs. You can stand strong  on the inside too. (beat) Know what I mean?

Guadalupe nods. Roberta holds out the violin case. Guadal lunges forward and hugs her around the waist. Roberta  awkwardly accepts the hug, startled and touched by it, an strokes the girl's hair. Guadalupe lets go, takes the vio and exits. HOLD ON ROBERTA as she absorbs what just happe JANET pokes her head into the room.
You wanted to speak to me?
Oh. Umm -- that's O.K. It's taken  care of.
Janet looks at her curiously, then exits.

Roberta walks around an empty, rundown apartment, her  expression somber. Crayon markings on the walls, cigarett burns on the floors, a filthy bathroom and kitchen. An ol Puerto Rican woman stands back as Roberta inspects the pl Roberta wipes grease off one of the windows.
Is just for you and your boys?
Yes.
No husband? No boyfriend?
A beat.
No.
Roberta enters the yard from inside the school. It's fill with kids playing, including Nick and Lexi. She waves to  them and Lexi runs up to her, carrying a piece of artwork
Look what I made you, Mommy!
He gives her a tempera PAINTING of a man's face, the  background decorated with glued-on macaroni. It says DADD
(covering her  discomfort) That is so beautiful!

He runs off. Roberta exhales, sits down alone on a bench takes out her lunch. She smiles at ALICE CROWLEY and anot TEACHER but they cross to another bench. ISABEL VASQUEZ ( approaches, a lively Puerto Rican woman with a strong New York accent.
Whatsa matter -- you got cooties?
Apparently.
I'll take my chances. (extends a hand) Isabel Vasquez. Second grade.
Roberta Demetras. I'm the --
Violin teacher. I know.
She sits down beside Roberta, takes out her lunch.
Is it my imagination, or does everyone  hate me?

It's hard to fit in when you're doing  a special program. People figure  you're not gonna be here very long,  so why make the effort? (beat) It may take a while for folks to  warm up, but nobody hates you.
(sotto) What about Alice Crowley?
(sotto) A) she thinks the violin's a waste  of time... and B) -- she's a bitch.
Roberta laughs.
And then there's Dennis.
The Music Man. You've had the bodacity  to threaten his private little empire --  not to mention the fact that you  messed up his sacred scheduling chart.
How come you're being nice to me?
Ulterior motives. I want my daughter  in your class next year.
Roberta smiles.
If I'm here next year.
You will be.

LEXI'S PAINTING is on the wall, along with a crayon drawi of himself, Roberta, and Nick in front of a house. ANGLE - ROBERTA looks out the window. She's gotten some u furniture, cleaned the place, and it's less depressing.

On the street below, three prostitutes stand at the corne Two men sit on a stoop, smoking a joint, and in a parked  car, three men seem to be making a drug deal. One of the  buildings on the street is burned out, missing a front do
Nick, in his pajamas, enters and crosses to his mother. S smiles at him and they both look out the window.
In Greece, we could see the ocean.  Remember?
I remember. And the fishing boats...
And the octopuses.
Roberta smiles and puts her arm around him.
Is Daddy coming here soon?
Roberta tenses up.
Well, that's something I've been  wanting to talk to you about. Daddy's  not gonna live with us anymore. You  and Lexi will have special times  when you stay with him, like at  Christmas.
A beat.
Can you tell the birthday story?
Roberta looks at him, concerned that he's not responding her news.
Don't you want to talk about what I  told you?
I want to hear the birthday story.
A beat as she contemplates whether to push or not, then:
It was the day of Grandpa's birthday,  and I was sad because he had died a  few months back.
But you knew I'd be born that day.
So I packed a bag and got all ready --
And Daddy laughed.
I said, "It's my father's birthday,  and the baby's gonna be born today."
He didn't believe you. But I was  born. The same day as Grandpa.
It was a happy day.
Was Daddy happy too?
She looks at him, taken aback by the question.
Of course he was.
Then why is he leaving me?
Roberta, overcome with emotion, can barely answer.
He's not leaving you, Nick. He loves  you and Lexi very much.
Then why can't he live here?
(struggling) It's very hard to explain... Sometimes  things happen between grown-ups...  and they just can't be together.
The CAMERA moves behind them as they continue to look out the window, and we see Nick move away from his mother.
The kids play "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star" and they soun awful. Roberta looks disgusted as she leads them.
Slow bows! Slow bows! Don't squeeze!  Stop! Everybody stop! (to De Sean) How much did you practice this week?
My asthma -- it was very bad and I  had to go to the hospital.
Again? You told me you went to the  hospital last week.
Oh yeah. Maybe it was last week.
Roberta rolls her eyes, then turns to Lucy.
Lucy -- you sounded the worst of  all. Have you practiced?
No.
Why not? You can't be in this class  if you don't practice!
My grandma got mugged.
A beat.
Oh. I'm sorry. Is she O.K.?
She died.
Roberta stands there, sobered.
I'm really sorry, Lucy. (tries to get her  bearings) Just do the best you can.

A group of kids stand together with their violins and cha Roberta exits the building and they greet her. She waves  back, but she's clearly still upset by her interaction wi Lucy. She sees Naeem and his mother and approaches them.
Hi, Roberta.
Hi, Naeem. Can I talk to your mom  for a minute?
Naeem nods and moves off.

Look, I didn't come up here to rescue  anybody. I'm a single mother and I  needed a job. And I know you think  you're protecting your son, but you're  not. I mean, what if Arthur Ashe's  mother had stopped him from playing  tennis because it's a "white man's  game"? (beat) The important thing is that when  Naeem plays music, his whole face  lights up. You should see him.
Mrs. Adisa takes this in. Roberta exits. Mrs. Adisa looks for Naeem and sees him watching the violin students, long to be among them. She watches her son with compassion.

Roberta and the boys shop in a colorful outdoor produce m in their neighborhood. The boys suddenly rush over to A MAN sitting on the groun with mixed-breed PUPPIES in a cardboard box. The boys pet them excitedly. Roberta watches her sons; they're happier than she's seen them in ages.
A brown puppy is jumping all over Nick and Lexi who laugh delightedly. Roberta is putting down newspapers.
We all have to take turns cleaning  up, O.K.?
The boys are oblivious to her -- they're in heaven.
(to herself) Yeah, right.
Roberta's SCREAMING at the kids as they play "Twinkle Twi Little Star."

First finger on the E! Three -- two --  one -- open! (to a white girl with  pigtails) Wrong string, Becky! We've done this  fourteen times! And look at your  nails! You're supposed to cut them  for violin class! O.K, everybody  stop! It sounds horrible! I can't  believe how bad it sounds!
They stop playing. Tanisha raises her hand.
Is this an important question,  Tanisha?
Tanisha nods.
Do you have two of those skirts?
What?
You wore a skirt just like it on  Monday.
Some of the kids crack up.
You know, Tanisha -- I don't think  that's such an important question. (to class) O.K. Let's try --
The door opens and Naeem enters with Mrs. Adisa. Roberta  crosses to them.
Naeem and I were wondering if he  could still be in the class.
A beat.
I'd love that. (to Naeem) You'll have a lot of catching up to  do. You think you can work that hard?
Yeah, I can.
Maybe we can also arrange some private  lessons at my house.
I wouldn't have the money for that.
That's O.K. (to Naeem) Why don't you go grab one of my spare  violins?
Naeem happily runs to the extra violins at the front of t room; Mrs. Adisa nods to Roberta with a look of gratitude then exits. Roberta crosses back to the front of the room
(to class) Let's try it again.
They begin again, and we see Naeem take out a violin and  join in. As they play, Roberta's ears perk up at somethin she's hearing. She crosses to Lucy.
What are you playing?
Twinkle.
(to class) Everyone stop! (to Lucy) Let me hear.
Lucy hesitates, thinking she's in trouble. She plays a ja variation of the song. Roberta smiles.
Did someone teach you that?
No. I made it up.
That's really great, Lucy. I'm proud  of you.
Lucy beams.
(to class) All of you -- try it.
The class plays Lucy's jazz variation and Naeem happily j in.
Roberta sits opposite Janet and MRS. LAMB, a white woman her 30's.
You're shouting at them. All the  time.
Not all the time. But if they don't  listen --
Didn't you tell them that they were  making their parents sick?
Janet raises her eyebrows at this.
That wasn't exactly what I said --
I'm raising Becky in a supportive  atmosphere. I don't send her to school  to be abused.
I'm just trying to discipline them.  If they're gonna learn an instrument,  they need to take it seriously --
I think what Mrs. Lamb is trying to  say, Roberta, is that you're a little  too harsh. I'm sure you might be  able to soften some of your comments  to the children?
She gives Roberta a long hard look. Roberta nods.
Roberta listens to the students play "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" badly. They finish and stare at her, afraid of her respon
Well, that was... that was pretty  good... that wasn't too bad...
They look at her in disbelief, then look at each other.
It wasn't? I thought we stunk.
I wouldn't put it that way... You  all just need to practice a bit more. (to James) James, have you practiced this week?
The boy nervously shakes his head no.
Can you please try a little harder  for next week?
James nods. The kids are baffled by her politeness.
Good. Just do the best you can.
Why you acting like that?
Like what?
Nice.
Don't you want a nice teacher?
I already got nice teachers. You  added some variety.
Yeah. We like you better the way you  used to be.
Oh. (to Becky) What about you, Becky?
Yeah. This is even worse. You're  acting weird now.
A beat.
Well, then -- I take it back. You  all stunk.
The kids laugh.
But don't tell your parents I said  so!
The kids laugh again.
Christmas MUZAK plays in the b.g. as Roberta kisses and h Lexi and Nick goodbye. A FLIGHT ATTENDANT stands nearby.
Can't you come with us? Please?
Honey, I told you. This is Daddy's  special time with you.
Lexi looks upset; Nick is stoic. Roberta hugs them one la time. The FLIGHT ATTENDANT steps forward.
I'll take good care of them.

The FLIGHT ATTENDANT escorts them into the jet way. Rober holds back tears as they get further away from her. At th last moment, Lexi turns and waves; Nick does not. Roberta waves, tears starting to fall, and the boys disappear fro sight. She observes all the families travelling together, and feels like the loneliest person in the airport.

Roberta enters her apartment, back from the airport, and  double-locks the door behind her. You can see on her face that she's dreading the emptiness. She crosses to a small Christmas tree, obviously decorated by her and the boys, plugs in the tiny blinking lights. It's not exactly  Rockefeller Center. She turns on the T.V., playing IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE. She crosses to the kitchen, then returns with a carton of eggnog, a glass, and a bottle of rum. She sits down on th couch, pours herself some eggnog, adds rum, adds more rum goes back into the kitchen, returns with nutmeg, sprinkle some on top, then drinks. She sighs, glancing miserably a the tree and the T.V. Pathetic. She couldn't look any les festive if she tried. There's a KNOCK on the DOOR. Roberta gets up and warily approaches the door.
Who is it?
Santa Claus.

She looks through the peephole, then quickly unlocks the  door and opens it, revealing BRIAN, giving her a big smil He looks sexy as hell (even with a silly lit-up Santa Cla pin on his leather jacket), and he holds a long-stemmed r rose in one hand, and a Christmas present in the other.
I'm back.
Roberta's thrilled and relieved to see him. She embraces  him, and they kiss passionately.
CLOSE ON plaster walls being knocked down with sledgehamm REVEAL Brian, Roberta, and a couple of workmen knocking d the walls in an old brownstone.

A mild winter day. Roberta, covered with plaster dust and overheated from working, leans against a car and drinks a beer. The three-story brick building has some graffiti on and is badly in need of a paint job; there are a few brok windows, and the front stairs need repairing. WORKMEN fil in and out. We can see from the STREET SIGNS that we're o 118th STREET, a few houses off FIRST AVENUE. Brian (also dust-covered), Nick and Lexi toss around a  football. LAWRENCE (6), a Black boy who lives next door,  joins them. Brian crosses to Roberta, sweaty and out of  breath. He takes a swig of her beer.
O.K., enough goofing off -- back to  work.
You trying to kill me?
She laughs and they kiss. ASSUNTA comes up the street with a bag of take-out food. casts a dubious glance at the lovers.
I was the only person in the whole  coffee shop not speaking Spanish.
Roberta rolls her eyes. O.S. a car BACKFIRES.
You hear that? Gunshots! How you  gonna live here by yourself? (calling) Boys, come eat!
I work in this neighborhood, Mama. I  want to live here.
The boys approach and Assunta hands them sandwiches. Lawr hangs back. Assunta calls to him.
What's your name?
Lawrence.
You hungry, Lawrence?
Lawrence nods and she hands him a sandwich. Roberta smile at her mother's gesture. The kids move off to Lawrence's  front steps and Assunta gives Roberta and Brian sandwiche
(to Brian) Why did you let her buy this house?
Hey, your daughter does what she  wants -- or haven't you noticed?
I've noticed.
Robert washes dishes and Assunta dries. The leftovers fro an Italian dinner are on the counter.
I still don't understand the rush.
Having my own place will make me  feel like I'm really starting my  life again.
But if you invested your divorce  settlement, you could buy something  nice someday. It's bad enough that  you've been renting in this  neighborhood, but to lock yourself  into a mortgage --
(snapping) Mama, please. Just stop!
Assunta backs off. Roberta feels guilty and moves to her.
Don't worry, O.K.? Besides, if things  keep going well, I'm sure eventually  Brian will move in with us.
A few beats.
How much do you know about this man?
Brian's a good person, he's helped  me a lot, he's great with the boys --  since he got back to town, it's been  really sweet.
(with an attitude) And how long has he been back?
Two months.
That's not very long. Don't make the  same mistake twice, Bert. You barely  knew Charles when you married him.
(defensive) I don't get it -- you're ragging on  me about buying the house -- I would  think you'd want Brian to live with  me.
Not if he's the wrong person.
Roberta locks her jaw, not wanting to believe that she's  right.
The kids play "Allegro," Roberta leading them.
Get ready, now -- we're coming up to  the fermata...
They reach a certain note, then pause.

Hold... Hold... Don't anybody move.  Now at the Spring Concert, the  audience is gonna be dying for that  next note -- but we'll make them  wait. As a matter of fact, I think  I'll go grab a cup of coffee.
She starts for the door and the kids moan and groan: "Com on, Roberta!" "Roberta, get back here!" She smiles.
Well, O.K. But you have to promise  you'll all start together.
She nods. They begin again -- all at different times.
Man. We'll never get that right.
That's not a very nice thing to say  about your classmates. (to class) How many people think they can get  it right by the concert?
All the kids raise their hands. De Sean looks around,  embarrassed, then raises his too. Roberta smiles.
Brian and Roberta finish making love on the futon. They l in each other's arms, still breathing heavily.
I love you.
Brian makes a sound that's either panting or laughing.
Did you just laugh?
I'm sorry. It's just...
Roberta looks at him, offended.
What?
Why do people feel like the minute  something's going great, they gotta  name it? (beat) Once you name something, you snuff  the life out of it.
She disentangles from him.
Jesus, Brian. Do you still get away  with that crap? It's not the Sixties  anymore.
Well, maybe if you'd actually gone  through the Sixties, you'd know what  I'm talking about.
Fine! We won't name it, we won't  talk about it, we'll act like we  have no feelings for each other  whatsoever!
She angrily turns on her side with her back to him. Brian regrets hurting her and moves to her, kissing her shoulde
I'm sorry. I'm being an asshole. (sweetly teasing) You can say you love me if you want.
Forget it. I changed my mind.
He laughs and coaxes her to kiss him -- a temporary truce
ERNIE (70's), a rickety Black man in work boots, looks ba by a tangled mess of wires protruding from a wall. Robert approaches.
How's it coming, Ernie?
Well, if I could just remember what  I did here yesterday, I'd be moving  a whole lot faster. (beat) You look real pretty today, honey.
Brian overhears, rolls his eyes and pulls her aside.
You're crazy. Why did you hire him?
He needed a job. Besides, he's wired  all of East Harlem.
When? Fifty years ago?
Brian sighs and walks off into another room. Two MEN carr in large panels of sheetrock with old WALLPAPER on it.
Why is there wallpaper on it?
That's how it comes.
They lean the panels against a wall. Roberta turns to Ern
Yep, that's how it comes now.
The guys quickly exit. Brian re-enters and sees the panel
What the hell is this?
Sheetrock.
You've gotta be kidding. Those ex- cons you hired ripped this off --  and you too!
Roberta feels stupid but doesn't want to show it.
Look -- this house is taking every  penny of my settlement. I can't afford  fancy union workers!
(throwing up his hands) Fine. Do it your way.
He stomps off. ANOTHER ANGLE - Nick watches them fight an looks distressed.

Lots of screaming and commotion as the kids crowd around fight in progress. As we move through the crowd we see th NICK's in a fight with another boy; Nick's nose is bleedi and he has the boy in a headlock. TWO TEACHERS run over t break it up.
Nick sits outside, holding an ice pack to his bloody nose
Roberta stands opposite Janet.
I'm giving him a two-day suspension --  but next time he'll be expelled.
There won't be a next time -- I  promise.
Have you noticed your son lately?  He's tied up in knots and he needs  help.
Janet, kids fight. You're making too  much of this.
He was choking the kid. (beat) Nick's in trouble, Roberta. You need  to deal with it.
Roberta takes this in, upset.

Roberta plays "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" with Guadalupe, De Sea Naeem, Benjamin, and two kids from the other classes. Lex plays along with them. Nick enters from the kitchen, eati a cookie, ignoring the students. He turns on the T.V.
(to students) Keep playing, guys.
Roberta crosses to Nick and shuts off the T.V.
You can watch when we're done.
It's my house! They don't live here --  I do!
(sotto) Nick honey -- the kids are real  nervous about the Spring concert.  You could probably give them some  pointers.
I don't feel like it.
He reaches for the T.V. dial and she stops him.
I said no.
She crosses back to her students; Nick turns on the T.V.
Brian, Nick and Lexi laugh as they play frisbee alongside DUCK POND. Roberta watches, relieved to see Nick enjoying himself.
Good catch Nick!
Nick throws it back to Brian and it lands in the WATER.
(mock sternly) Uh-oh. You know what that means?
He stalks towards Nick menacingly, picks him up and prete he's going to throw him into the water. Nick laughs  hysterically.
(through laughter) Don't! Don't throw me in!
Whatsa matter? Afraid of a little  water? The ducks aren't afraid! Are  you a chicken or a duck?
Don't! Don't throw me!
Looks like you got yourself a chicken,  Roberta!
I'm not a chicken!
Well then you must be a duck!
He pretends again to throw Nick in, then puts him down. L holds out his arms to Brian.
Throw me in the water, Brian! Do it  to me!
Brian swoops him up and Lexi starts laughing. Roberta lau along, happy to see the affection between Brian and her s
Brian and Roberta speak as they stroll; the boys run ahea of them, dragging sticks along the pavement. In the b.g. see HARLEM STREETS bordering the park.
You seem to be the only one who can  get Nick to laugh these days.
He misses his dad. I'm just a  surrogate.
No -- I think Nick really likes you. (taking his arm) You know... we're all hoping you'll  move into the new house with us.
Whoa. Can we just slow down here a  minute? It's too much like getting  married.
What's so bad about that?
That kind of commitment just isn't  realistic. I mean, how can we know  that you and I will even be able to  stand each other in five years?
Well, we don't. But if two people  care about each other, they take a  chance.
And look what happened to you and  Charles.
I'm not talking about Charles. I'm  talking about us.
Look, Roberta. Marriage is based on  a belief that one person can  completely meet another person's  needs. I just don't buy that.
This is making her nervous. She looks at him, afraid of w he might be saying.
(carefully) What are you saying? If there's some  need you have that I don't meet,  you'd go and get it "met" by someone  else?
He heaves a sigh of frustration, not wanting to answer th question.
I'm saying that it's the 80's and  it's a fantasy to think of marriage  lasting these days. One out of two  marriages ends in divorce!

You didn't answer my question. (beat) If I don't meet all your needs, and  we're in a committed relationship --  forget marriage for a minute; I'm  just talking about a relationship --  would you go to someone else?
A beat.
In theory, yes.
In theory.
Roberta looks very disheartened. Brian feels badly.
Roberta, we've got something good  right now -- that's the important  thing. Let's just keep it that way,  O.K.?
He pulls her to him, kissing her neck, but she pulls away from him. ON NICK, observing with an anxious expression.
(whining) Why can't he?
Roberta looks distressed by her talk with Brian as she an the boys enter, back from the park.
He just can't, O.K.? Brian's at his  house tonight, and we're at ours.
Well then I wanna go to his house.
Enough, Nick. Now why don't you and  your brother practice while I make  dinner.
I don't feel like practicing.
Well do it anyway.
I wanna go to Brian's!
Stop whining, and get your violin.

Nick stomps off to get his violin. Lexi follows. Roberta  puts down her bag and takes off her coat. While Lexi sets his violin, Nick opens his violin case, takes out the vio and angrily starts playing, loudly and roughly.
What the hell are you doing?
The problem with you is you're mean  to everybody and then they don't  want to be with you!
I've heard just about enough from  you, young man. Now set your violin  up properly and start practicing.
Nick THROWS the violin against the floor. Roberta's  speechless.
I hate the violin!
You pick that violin up right now  and don't you ever ever --
Nick picks up the violin and THROWS the violin down even  harder, then YELLS at Roberta before she can even respond
It's all your fault! You made Daddy  leave and you're gonna make Brian  leave too! You're gonna be all alone  and I'll have to take care of you!
Roberta is stunned. The anger drains out of her as she  suddenly sees what this is all about.
Nick -- you don't have to take care  of me.
Then who's going to?
I'll take care of myself -- and I'll  take care of you and Lexi. I promise.
You didn't try hard enough. You made  Daddy leave us.
This hits her in the solar plexus. Her hurt and vulnerabi start to pour out.
That's not true. I begged him not to  leave, but he didn't listen.
Why not?
Roberta hesitates, but knows she has to tell them the tru She addresses both boys.
Your father met someone he liked  more than Mommy, and then --
Who?
Roberta swallows, shocked to hear him ask this. She can h answer him.
Lana. Remember our friends Lana and  Tom?
Is he gonna marry her now?
No, but he's not coming back... to  me.
Nick and Lexi look very upset, not only from hearing the  finality in her words, but from seeing their mother's pai Roberta moves closer to them.
I'll take care of you, Nick. You  too, Lexi. I promise. I'm not going  anywhere. We're still a family.
Nick starts crying. Roberta takes him in her arms. Lexi s to cry and Roberta holds him too.
(softly, to both) I promise.

Ernie's radio plays a BLUES SONG. The BRICK WORKERS radio plays SPANISH MUSIC, and the PAINTERS' radio plays a RAP  SONG. Roberta stands in the middle, about to lose her min HER POV - Ernie sits on a stool facing his wiring. He's f asleep. ANOTHER ANGLE - The brick workers build a crooked fireplace.
Roberta sighs heavily, then crosses to the painters.
What color is this?
White.
I told you Eggshell.
Eggshells are white.
Brian watches this interaction as he sands a door.
You're an idiot! I told you -- you  can't be your own contractor.
You're right. I'm an idiot.
She crosses to Ernie and shakes him.
Wake up, Ernie.
He looks at her groggily.
You're fired.
She crosses to the brick workers.
You're fired.
She crosses to the painters.
You're fired.
Brian smiles at her, impressed.
That's more like it.
You're fired too.
Brian laughs.
No, Brian. I mean it. I need to be  with a man who can make a commitment  to me. I need that, and my sons need  that. (beat) So can you?
(hesitates, then) Roberta --
His tone and expression tell her the words are not  forthcoming.
Get out.
He looks at her, shocked by her toughness, but knows he c give her what she wants. He exits. Roberta stands in the  middle of the room, a determined look on her face.
Stands in the aisle, leading the students and playing vio

The fifty fifth-grade students play the "Twinkle" variati Their playing is impeccable and they look terrific. As the CAMERA PANS the audience, we recognize: MRS. ADISA tears in her eyes as she watches Naeem; MRS. LAMB and her husband, watching Becky in amazement; ISABEL and her daug sitting with ASSUNTA, NICK and LEXI; JANET, impressed as  hell; and DENNIS, seething with jealousy. As the kids sta the jazz variation of "Twinkle," a WOMAN elbows her husba
That's the one Lucy wrote!
The CAMERA returns to the children and captures their own pride in their playing, including LUCY, who smiles as she hears her song played by fifty.

The students are now playing "Allegro," and they reach th fermata. They hold their positions in silence and the aud watches in anticipation. Roberta cues them and they play next note in perfect unison. An involuntary smile lights DE SEAN's face. They finish the song, the audience applau and Roberta turns to face them. She lights up when she sees how thrilled Janet looks, and Janet in turn raises her hands higher as she applauds Rob

The side of the building now has an impressive mural: an  urban landscape with three super heroes -- Puerto Rican,  Black, and white -- rising up out of the street. It reads ONLY THE STRONG SHALL SURVIVE.

Roberta stands in front of a classroom of twenty cute fir graders -- mostly Black and Latino, a few white -- sittin on the floor, chatting excitedly. Even though Roberta's t years older, she seems more youthful; her wavy hair is lo over her shoulders, her clothing's casual and artistic. B her is Janet, her hair flecked with gray, and Dennis, who looks pretty much the same. The classroom teacher is ISAB a little older, a little tougher.
C'mon everybody, settle down -- Janet  wants to talk to you.

Today's a very special day because  we're starting the tenth year of the  East Harlem Violin Program. This is  a wonderful opportunity for you, so  I want you to talk to your parents  about whether you'd like to try this.
My daughter took violin with Roberta  when she was your age, and now she's  in high school and she still talks  about how much she loved it.
Janet and I started this program  because we knew how much you kids  could benefit from it.
CUTAWAY to Roberta and Janet exchanging glances over Denn taking credit for the program.
You should know, however, that the  violin is a difficult instrument.
JUSTIN, a Black boy with attitude, raises his hand. He al wears a puffy red, yellow and green crocheted beret. Isab nods to him.
Who's that lady in the back?
ANGLE - DOROTHEA (Doro-taya) VAN HAUFTEN (40's), an elega beautiful woman, smartly dressed, takes photographs from back of the room.
That's Dorothea Van Hauften --
Say what? What kinda name is that?
Justin -- sshh!
-- and she's taking pictures of  Roberta's classes for a magazine  article about music education.
I wanna be in the magazine!
First things first, Justin. Roberta's  gonna explain to you about the  "lottery."
Roberta steps forward. RAMON OLIVAS (7), a small, adorabl Puerto Rican boy with a crew cut, watches her with adorat

I used to just teach fifty kids at  this school. But now I teach a hundred  and fifty kids at three East Harlem  schools and there's so many children  who want to take violin classes that  we have to have a lottery.
VANESSA raises her hand, a white girl whose clothes and  accessories are always adorned with cats.
Can I be in the class?
Roberta's explaining that. Just  listen.
After your parents sign your  permission slips, I'm gonna put them  in a sack, and I'll pick fifty names  from each school.
ANGLE - Ramon listens intently with his fingers crossed.
So everyone bring in your slips by  Friday, and I'll come back and tell  you who's in violin class.
Remember, she's just picking names  from a hat. It doesn't mean that  anyone's better than anyone else.
RAMON raises his hand.
(to Roberta) I really really hope that I get in  the class.
Roberta looks at him, struck by his sweetness.
I hope so too.

The brownstone looks a lot better than when we last saw i Graffiti's been removed, the stairs have been repaired, t windows have security bars, and there are flowers bloomin in pots in front of the building. Roberta steps INTO FRAM walking Allegra, now a 10-year-old dog.

The house is transformed: the first floor is one long ope room with oak floors, a living room in front with a beaut fireplace and a grand piano, and a country kitchen in the rear, complete with pots hanging over a large butcher blo NICK (17) practices cello and LEXI (15) practices piano;  they play Haydn's "Trio #13." Now handsome young men, the blonde hair has darkened to brown. Nick is huskier; Lexi a slighter build. Both are passionate, talented musicians On the couch, RACHEL (12), a mature, beautiful Black girl rosins her bow.
How come you guys don't play the  violin?
Well, picture her being your teacher  and your mother.
Rachel cracks up but stifles her laughter as Roberta ente from outside with Allegra.
Hi Rachel. Be right with you.
As Roberta removes Allegra's leash, Rachel and Lexi share conspiratorial look. In the b.g., Nick packs up his cello
(to Nick) You're gonna practice upstairs?
No. I'm done.
Already? You've barely practiced.
What -- are you timing me with a  stop watch? Why don't you pick on  Lexi for a change?
'Cause I'm perfect.
Nick jostles him and heads upstairs. Lexi gets up from th piano.
(to Rachel) Have a good lesson.
He crosses to a sharp-looking bike parked behind the fron door and addresses Roberta.
I'll be back in a couple of hours.
Be careful.
Lexi mouths "be careful" along with her.

Lexi plays basketball with a group of Black and Latino gu Despite his small stature, he's a great athlete, and an  accepted part of the group. The game ends. He and his bud Lawrence (now 16), both all sweaty, cross to a water foun As Lexi takes a drink --
Can I try your bike?
Lexi wipes his mouth and looks up at HENRY (18), a tall,  intimidating Black teenager who towers over him. Lawrence watches tensely.
I'm gonna be leaving pretty soon.
Just wanna take it for a spin.
C'mon, Henry -- he don't want to  loan you his bike.
I didn't hear him say that. (to Lexi) Is that true? Did you say that?
Lexi looks at him, knowing there's only one right answer.
Roberta and Rachel play Bach's "Minuet One" together on t violin. The girl has obvious talent.
Vibrato... don't wiggle your wrist.
Rachel stops, frustrated.
Dang! I can't get that right.
You almost have it.
Almost isn't good enough.
Did I turn you into such a  perfectionist?
No. I came that way.
(smiles, then) Just as long as you get it right for  your Julliard audition.
What?
I've recommended you for a gifted  kids scholarship.
Rachel looks at her in wide-eyed gratitude. ANGLE - Lexi enters the front door, a glum look on his fa
Where's the bike?
Roberta drives with Nick in the front, Lexi and Lawrence the back. They're in a dangerous looking part of East Har
Mom, please. Don't do this to me!
C'mon, Mom -- why don't you let me  handle this?
Are we getting closer, Lawrence?
It's the next block up.
(to Roberta) You don't have to do this. I'll pay  you back.
How? It took me six months to save  up for it.
I'll help him, O.K.? We'll both pay  you back.
Or we'll ask Dad -- he'll help us  out.
Yeah, right.
O.K., slow down. It's the second one  on the right.
Roberta slows the car down next to a HOUSING PROJECT.
Not a place you'd want to go into, even in the day time. PULL BACK TO REVEAL this is their POV from INSIDE THE CAR The boys look frightened, but Roberta's on a mission.
C'mon Mom, let's get out of here.
Lock the doors.
And she exits. The boys watch as she heads for the buildi then Lexi shakes his head and covers his face.
I'm dead. She's gonna get me killed.
Nick jumps out of the car and heads after her.
I'm coming with you!
No. Get back in the car and stay  with the boys.
Nick hesitates and heads back. Roberta presses on. Lawren opens the window and calls to her.
Don't take the stairs!

CLOSE ON THE ELEVATOR DOOR with a handwritten SIGN that r OUT OF ORDER. WIDER - Roberta stands in front of the elevator, staring  tensely at the sign. She takes a deep breath, then heads the staircase.
Roberta climbs the dimly-lit stairs of a dilapidated, sca building. O.S. a BABY CRIES, a couple of TV's BLARE.
At the top of the stairs, Roberta turns down the hall, pa a door riddled with bullet holes. She finds the apartment and knocks. No response. She knocks again.
Yeah?
I'm a school teacher. Henry has taken  my son's bicycle and I want it back.
A beat, then the door cracks open, an OLD WOMAN visible  through the chain lock.
Henry's not here.
Well you tell Henry that if he returns  the bike, I won't have to notify the  police -- or his school principal.  Although since I am a teacher, it  would be very easy for me to do that.
A couple of beats.
He's not home. He doesn't get home  till late.
How late?
Not till after ten.
I'll be on the steps of CPE 1 at 11  P.M. I'll be waiting for him.
The door closes. Roberta exhales. Did she just do that?
Roberta, Nick, Lexi and Lawrence sit on the front steps o the school. The street is deserted.
You're crazy. He's not gonna show.
Roberta sits confidently.
You think he actually cares that  you're a teacher? You think he even  goes to school?
C'mon, Mom -- let's just go.
It's only five after eleven.

Nick and Lexi roll their eyes and exchange a look: she's  nuts. Suddenly, there's the SOUND of a bicycle. Nick, Lex and Lawrence look towards the sound, incredulous. Lexi st Henry rides up on the bike and dismounts. Lexi looks dire at him as he takes the bike from him.
I was just borrowing it.
He glances at Roberta, then walks off.
Roberta stands in front of Isabel's class and calls out n handing the selected children acceptance letters. The kid are charged up; "My heart is pounding!" "Please pick me!"
Shandra Wilson.

A pretty Black girl with braids and tons of barrettes jum up and down, then runs up for her letter. The kids SQUEAL and CHEER for each student called. Shandra hugs her best  friend MYESHA, a chubby Black girl who also holds a lette
Justin Brady.
JUSTIN raises his fists in triumph. ANGLE - RAMON anxious waits to see if his name will be called. JUSTIN sits down next to him, waves his letter in Ramon's face, taunting h
Vanessa Klein.
Vanessa takes her letter and smiles. She puts it into her cat-shaped backpack.
O.K. One more name...
Ramon crosses his fingers and holds his breath.
Leonard Hood.
RAMON looks crushed. JUSTIN taunts him some more. LEONARD scrawny white boy takes his letter, scared by it. He star to cry.
It's too hard! I don't wanna do it!
Don't you even wanna try, Leonard?
(through tears) I don't want to!
Isabel looks at Roberta.
Well, O.K. then. I'll pick someone  else. (she picks a name) Ramon Olivas.
Ramon's face lights up.

As Roberta walks through the yard, she sees kids excitedl showing acceptance letters to their moms. SHANDRA and MYESHA hold hands as they run to Shandra's mo BEVERLY WILSON, pushing a stroller. She looks at the lett and hugs Shandra. ANGLE - RAMON reads his letter to his mother, CONCEPCION  (45), whose eyes tell you that she's lived through a lot. She speaks with a Puerto Rican accent.
This is to inform you that your child,  Ramon Olivas, has been chosen by  lottery to be in the violin program.
You happy?
Ramon spins round and round with the letter in his hand.
I think you're happy.
Roberta illegally parks her old Honda, rushes out of the  car, grabs her book bags and three violins, pulls a parki ticket from her pocket and puts it on the windshield.
(German accent) Does that really work?
Roberta turns. It's DOROTHEA, the PHOTOGRAPHER we saw in classroom.
No. But I keep trying. And maybe  someday the school will give me a  parking space!
She rushes towards the school and Dorothea follows her.
Wait --
She hands Roberta a thin box. Roberta puts down her violi glances inside it and forgets about being late.
-- Terrific black and white shots of Roberta's advanced  classes playing violin.
God, these are great.
Those copies are for you.
Thank you. Can I... pay for you them?
Don't be silly. Besides -- you'll  need your money for parking tickets.
They smile at each other.
What you're doing for these children  is wonderful. My husband's a violinist --  he was quite impressed when I told  him about you.
What's his name?
Arnold Steinhardt.
Of the Guarneri String Quartet?
Dorothea nods, and hands Roberta a card.
Stay in touch. Let us know when the  kids have a concert.
RACHEL, heading for school, calls out to Roberta.
Don't be late for violin class! I  hear the teacher's really mean.
Roberta smiles, slips the card in her pocket, nods to Dor and follows Rachel.
Roberta's advanced class plays "Can-Can." Rachel's one of the eight sixth-graders. Roberta plays along, crossing to AMANDA, a white girl in a country-western outfit.
Amanda, what did I tell you about  wearing cowboy boots to violin class?  They're too slippery!
She crosses to a pudgy Black/Puerto Rican boy with glasse
Relax your two, Simon...
She glances at STEPHANIE, a white girl with red hair, nex to KENNY, a Black boy with an earnest expression.
Your stop sign has to be up, Kenny!  Stephanie, it doesn't look like you  ever had a lesson with me!
CARLOS (13) hurries in, a handsome Black boy in a basebal jacket that says "LOS LEONES." He looks 15.
Where's your violin, Carlos?
It's coming.
He nervously looks down the hall.
What, is it walking here by itself?
A Black third-grade girl rushes into the room and hands C his violin, then runs off. Roberta crosses to Carlos as h quickly readies the violin.
Your buddies giving you a hard time?
Look, it's just not cool. You wouldn't  understand.
Hey, you want your sister to carry  your violin, that's fine. But is she  practicing for you too? Because  lately, that's how it sounds.
I've been busy! I've been --
I'm not interested! Just get here on  time, and commit to this class or I  don't want you in here, you  understand?
He nods sullenly.
You're a good violinist, Carlos --  and it's definitely not "cool" to  waste your own talent.
Carlos takes this in as Roberta crosses to another studen
It's upstairs from a grocery store on a busy street.

Ramon sits on the floor, upset, half-heartedly building w Legos, while his parents argue in the KITCHEN. His father MANUELO is a stocky, muscular man. INTERCUT between the t areas. This is a modest, well-kept apartment. Off the kit religious candles burn on a shelf above a washing machine
Why didn't you show it to me?
It just needed one parent's signature.
(with some Spanish) Well, I'm his parent and I don't  give permission! He should be playing  baseball, not the violin!
It makes him happy.
ON RAMON, looking far from happy at the moment.
Rachel steps off a city bus, carrying her violin. She pas two sixth-grade boys and a girl.
(loudly) Ooh, check out little Miss Violinhead.
She carry that violin with her all  the time 'cause she think she special.
Rachel turns to them.
I am special.
She proudly continues on, then sees Roberta walking towar the school and catches up to her.
(nonchalant) So I heard from Julliard.
Roberta stops and looks at her.
And?
They said yes!
Roberta gives her a big hug.

ON THE BEGINNER'S CLASS, including Ramon, as they play  "Lightly Row." Roberta walks around, making corrections a she addresses the students. She doesn't see Justin poking Ramon with his bow; Ramon swats the bow away and glares a his nemesis. Roberta moves some of Shandra's braids away  from the violin.
So when you take the violins home,  tape your music to the wall directly  in front of your nose so you can  play with perfect posture. Your  parents are gonna be so excited to  hear you play!

SCREECHING comes from Ramon's room as he practices "Light Row." His brothers, PEDRO (18) and ERNESTO (17), cringe a they try to watch T.V. Ernesto gives up and puts on his  Walkman; Pedro's ready to break the violin. Concepcion li patiently as she folds laundry, but even she winces.
(yelling) Ramon! How many cats you killing in  there?
INTERCUT RAMON - He plays with pride, eyes on the music t to the wall.

ON RAMON, his improved playing showing that time has pass WIDER - the beginner's class plays "Lightly Row." JUSTIN is struggling more than the other students. Robert plays along with the class, eyeing each student.
More bow! To the frog! Myesha, your  stop sign line should be touching.  Don't let it wiggle! You're on the  wrong string, Justin! And look at  your feet!
Vanessa enters the front door without her violin.
Where's your violin?
I forgot.
Goodbye! And you may be dropped.
Vanessa pouts and exits. Roberta moves to ROSARIO, a Puer Rican girl.
Look at those nails, Rosario!
She pulls a clipper from her pocket and swiftly clips the MYESHA nervously glances at her own nails.
I see you over there, Myesha.
She moves to Ramon and corrects his bowing position.
(to Ramon) You're doing much better.
As Roberta walks on to the next student, Justin purposely knocks over Ramon's music stand.
Drop dead, Justin!
It was a accident!
Was not!
Ramon, I don't like that kind of  talk. Justin, pick up his stand,  now! Our spring concert is in three  weeks and you might not be in it. Is  that what you want?
As Roberta heads for her car, she sees Vanessa being help into a car by her FATHER, his suit wrinkled and tie loose There's SNOW on the ground.
Mr. Klein? I'm gonna have to drop  Vanessa from the class if she keeps  forgetting her violin.
(sotto) She's going back and forth between  houses. My wife and I split up.
(softening) Oh. I'm sorry.
Roberta leans into the car window.
Vanessa, maybe you could write down  for your Mom and Dad which days are  violin days.
(almost in tears) The tape doesn't stick.
What?
I taped the music to the wall at my  Mom's house and then I took it to my  Dad's house and it doesn't stick  anymore.
Mr. Klein's eyes tear up and he quickly wipes them.
Well you know what? That's an easy  problem to solve.
She looks through her book bag, takes out a piece of musi and gives it to her.
Now you have two, O.K.? One for each  house.
Vanessa nods, clutching the piece of music. Roberta and M Klein exchange a look. She touches his arm, then walks of
Ramon, holding his bow and violin, crosses to his father  who's watching a baseball game on T.V.
You wanna hear my new song, Papa?
(in Spanish) Not right now.
Ramon exits, hurt. Concepcion watches from the side, and  crosses to her husband.
We made mistakes with Pedro and  Ernesto and we can't fix them now,  but Ramon -- he works so hard. The  violin makes him want to be good at  everything.
He shows no response, and she exits. Manuelo ponders what she said.

Roberta approaches the school on a winter morning. She sm as she sees Vanessa get out of her MOTHER'S car with her  violin. Roberta nears the front door and finds Isabel and some teachers huddled in conversation. A few students are crying.
(to Isabel) What happened?
The beginners sit on the floor and rosin their bows. A fe chat, but it's quieter than usual, except for RAMON who i "blessing" kids with his violin bow.
You go to heaven... You go to hell...  You go to hell... heaven...
Roberta enters slowly. She looks very shaken up. She take note of what Ramon is doing, and overhears Toussaint and  Shandra in mid-conversation.
My grandpa died and my uncle, so  that makes six.
I know more than that. At least seven  people... maybe even nine.
Roberta gently tells Ramon to sit, and then she sits down a child-sized chair in front of them.
(quietly) I know that you've all heard the bad  news about Justin.
I didn't hear.
There was a drive-by shooting by his  house and he got shot on accident  and he died.
Myesha takes this in, looking sad.
Does anyone want to talk about it?
(angry) I think we should just play violin.
Roberta watches him.
Concepcion cooks chicken and Pedro sets the table, whistl along to Ramon's O.S. violin playing "We Shall Overcome." There's a KNOCK on the door. Concepcion answers it, revea Roberta.
Roberta! Come in.
Roberta enters.
I came by to check on Ramon.
(confused) Why?
Didn't he tell you what happened at  school?
Concepcion shakes her head no.
Ramon is still playing violin as Concepcion and Roberta e When he sees Roberta he straightens up even more.
Roberta wants to talk to you, O.K.?
He nods. Concepcion touches his head, then exits.
Did that sound O.K.?
Yeah, it did.
Ramon smiles, pleased with himself.
I've been thinking about Justin.  Remember how mad I got the last time  I saw him?
Yeah. You got very strict with him.
It wasn't always so easy to be nice  to him, you know?
Ramon looks away from her, upset.
You think Justin's in heaven or hell?
Heaven.
Ramon runs his fingers along his bow.
I told him to drop dead.
Roberta touches Ramon's back.
Justin didn't die because of what  you said. I promise.
How do you know?
I don't think you're that powerful,  do you? I mean, if you had such  powers, just imagine what kind of  violin player you'd be by now!
Yeah. I'd be better than you!
They laugh together, then Ramon looks sad again.
It's O.K. to cry, you know.
