Not for a man.
My boys still cry and they're big,  strong young men now. (beat) I bet Justin's daddy cried.
Ramon's eyes get teary. Roberta quietly leaves the room.

Roberta brings in the mail, looking curiously at a manila envelope with a return address from the NY REVIEW OF BOOK She opens it, looks inside, then pours out a batch of oth letters onto the table. They're addressed to BOX HOLDER 1 She opens one, reads it, then rushes to an INTERCOM.
Nick, Lexi! Get down here right now!
We were just trying to help!
Nick and Lexi stand by the table, opposite Roberta -- wit the incriminating pile of letters between them.
This is humiliating!
Mom, no one knows it's you! I mean,  you don't even have to read them if  you don't want to. (glances at pile) Although obviously, a lot of guys  are interested in dating you.
No. A lot of guys are interested in  dating you and Lexi. (beat) What did you say about me, anyway?
They thought she'd never ask.
"Beautiful musician, late 40's, tired  of playing solo --
-- seeks a healthy, stable, attractive  man who's not afraid of a duet with  a strong, independent woman.
My violin playing will feed your  soul...
...And my lasagna will be music to  your palate."
They beam with pride. Roberta looks at them, mortified.
Oh, my God.
Did you catch all the music metaphors?
Don't you think it's a little weird  that you're trying to get your mother  a date?
Don't you think it's a little weird  that you're not even interested in  dating?
Boys, look. Number one -- even if I  wanted to date, I don't have time.  And number two -- I've got my  teaching, I've got you guys -- that's  all I need.
The boys nod, disappointed, and she exits. They look at e other with glum expressions.
(to Nick) I really thought she'd like the music  metaphors.
Roberta lies on the couch, reading the personal ad letter She tosses one aside, then opens another.
The letter is designed like a newspaper with a headline t reads: JOURNALISM PROFESSOR DAN PAXTON ANSWERS PERSONAL A

head_text.subj: HOPES RUN HIGH BEAUTIFUL MUSICIAN WILL CALL FOR A DATE

text: Roberta can't help but be charmed.
Roberta, Nick and Lexi play Haydn's "Trio #13" together o their respective instruments. We sense that this is a spe family ritual. They play throughout their conversation:
I think you're flat, Nick.
I'm not flat.
The B sounded flat.
Just play the violin, Mom. I'll take  care of the cello.
They play for a few beats.
You nervous, Mom?
No. I'm fine.
The DOORBELL rings and Roberta jumps up, bolting into the bathroom down the hall. Lexi and Nick exchange a smile, then Lexi crosses to the  door and opens it.
Standing in the doorway is a man in casual college profes attire. He's nice-looking, but no Prince Charming. He sha Lexi's hand and smiles warmly.
Hi. I'm Dan Paxton.
Lexi shows him in.
IN THE MIRROR - Roberta takes a last look at herself,  wondering if he'll find her attractive. She touches her h adjusts her dress, then takes a deep breath as she builds her courage.
Roberta enters the living room where Dan is chatting with Nick and Lexi. Dan sees her and is instantly smitten.
(shaking her hand) Wow. An honest woman.
Honest?
Your ad. When you said you were  beautiful, you were telling the truth.
She smiles, blushing, and avoids eye contact with her son who are trying really hard not to laugh. As she and Dan s to exit:
Make sure you're home by midnight,  young lady.
It reads 12:30. WIDER - Nick and Lexi play a video game on the TV screen. O.S., there's the SOUND OF A CAR. They race to the window
Ten bucks he tries to kiss her.
That's a no-brainer. Of course he'll  try. The real question is whether  she'll let him.
O.K. -- ten bucks she lets him.
You're on.
They stare out the window intently.
Dan pulls his car up in front of Roberta's house. Beside  him, Roberta holds a program from a Lincoln Center concer Roberta's tense, but Dan seems relaxed and centered in hi attraction to her.
I had a lot of fun tonight.
Yeah, I did too.
I have a confession -- I've never  answered an ad before. I did it on a  dare.
Well, I have a confession -- my boys  placed the ad behind my back.
They both laugh, then smile at each other. An awkward bea will he or won't he? Dan leans in to kiss her, and Robert turns away, uncertain.
Look, Dan -- I went along with this  'cause it's been a while. Quite a  while... And I had a very nice time...  but I'm not sure if I'm ready to get  involved with anyone right now.
A beat. Roberta feels badly about rejecting him.
(deadpan) Does this mean I don't get any  lasagna?
Roberta cracks up. Dan smiles at her.
Roberta enters. The boys are back to their video game,  covering that they've been spying on her.
Why are you guys still up?
(all innocence) Why? Is it late?
Good try, Nick.
So how was it?
Well... he's nice.
"Nice"? As in "let's just be friends"  nice?
I don't know yet. We'll see.
Nick looks disappointed.
There's still a lot more letters.
Good night, Nick.
She starts heading upstairs.
Hey, Mom -- can you loan me ten  dollars?
THE BLACKBOARD reads: SPRING CONCERT IN 10 DAYS! PRACTICE
Roberta rushes in, frazzled, not noticing at first that t beginners are very quiet -- and that most don't have viol
Guys, I'm so sorry -- I got stuck  over at CPE 2...
She puts her stuff down, then looks at the kids.
What's going on? Where are all your  violins?
We heard you got fired.
What?!
Janet and Dennis talk outside Janet's office. Roberta sto over to them. Janet looks at her, alarmed.
Is it true?
Why don't you come in my office?
It's true? You're firing me?
It's not me, Roberta. The Board of  Ed. cut the budget, the District had  to comply, and as of the end of this  term, the violin program has been...  excessed.
Roberta takes this in, momentarily speechless. In the b.g the beginners slip into the hall to watch.
Excessed. (beat) They specifically said that my violin  program has to go.
They've slashed the budget -- music  and art programs got hit the worst.
What about Dennis' classes?
I'm tenured, Roberta.
Roberta looks at him, then back to Janet.
When was this decided?
Things happened very quickly... I  wanted to tell you myself --
(reeling) I just... I can't even believe this  is happening!
Why not? You're a sub. Your position  has never been permanent.
Shut up, Dennis! You're not helping! (softly, to Roberta) Come into my office, please.
They leave Dennis standing there, looking as if he's had face slapped.
There's gotta be a way to fight this!
Fight it with what? I don't have any  other extra programs to give them  instead.
Oh, I see. So after ten years, after  fourteen hundred children have learned  to play the violin, this is just an  "extra program."
You know I don't feel that way and  you know damn well I've been standing  by you all these years! You think I  haven't noticed what you've done for  these kids?
Then do something!

(points to her phone) I've been on this phone for the past  three days trying to "do something" --  the District office can't even stand  the sound of my voice. Believe me,  there are some people around here  I'd much rather get rid of. But as  far as the Board's concerned, violin  classes are not a priority.
Roberta's fury starts to give way to grief. She looks ter wounded. Janet looks at her helplessly.
I don't have the power here, Roberta.  I'm so sorry.
A beat, and Roberta exits.
Roberta's dazed and in pain as she walks through the crow of children, oblivious to kids calling her name and wavin
Nick and Lexi enter the darkened house, chatting as Nick  wheels in the bike and Lexi bounces a basketball. They tu on a light to reveal
sitting at the kitchen table with a  glass of wine, her face ashen.
What happened?
Roberta, Nick and Lexi walk Allegra in their neighborhood Roberta looks worn out.
I'm a good teacher. I've worked so  hard to give these kids something to  be proud of.
Lexi moves to comfort her.
I'm so sorry, Mom. I can't believe  they did this to you.

It's like when my father got killed.  For twenty years, he followed every  safety rule the factory had, and  then someone else flips the wrong  switch... (she chokes up) It's not fair. You do everything  right and then...
It's the wrong analogy. You couldn't  do anything about Grandpa's death.  It was irreversible. This isn't.
Tell that to the Board of Education.
Let me ask you something. Why did  you risk your life for a bicycle?
Roberta and Lexi look at Nick, baffled as to the relevanc of the question.
I did not risk my life.
Of course you did! That building?  Threatening Henry? And for what --  two hundred dollars?
No. Not for that.
Then why?
When someone steals something that  belongs to my kids, I'm not gonna  sit back and let that happen!
A beat as she realizes what she's just said. The boys loo at her and the three of them stop walking.

Guys -- you need to think about this.  If I try to fight this -- with no  salary coming in -- I could lose the  house, screw up your college plans...  It would be a lot safer to just go  out tomorrow and get a job in a  private school.
Yeah, but is that where you really  want to be?

Roberta frantically searches through her purse, then cros to a hall closet and quickly checks the pockets of her co and jackets. She feels inside a jacket pocket, then finds it: DOROTHEA BUSINESS CARD.
FOLLOW DAN PAXTON as he walks down the hall towards his o and sees a strange silver object on the floor in front of his office door. He picks it up.
-- A foil-covered plate with a note on top: DO YOU KNOW A
Dan lifts up the foil to reveal a large piece of LASAGNA.

SEVENTY-FIVE KIDS play "We Shall Overcome" and it's incre moving. Nick's on cello, Lexi plays piano. ROBERTA proudl leads the children. At the side of the stage, we see DORO photographing the concert. THE CAMERA PANS THE AUDIENCE o teary-eyed parents, many of them with CAM CORDERS. We FIN Ramon's family. Manuelo is riverted by his son's playing, and he starts to cry. Concepcion knows this without looki She takes his hand. ANGLE - JANET stands along the side and her eyes start to fill with tears. She tries to stay composed, then discree exits the auditorium. The song ends and the audience APPLAUDS, rising from thei seats, including ASSUNTA (now 65), next to ISABEL and DAN Someone remains seated: a REPORTER (40's), sitting beside Dan and taking notes. The STUDENTS bow, then point to Roberta who bows and take the stage. She gestures for people to sit. A beginner stu brings her flowers. Roberta kisses her, then approaches t mike.

(to the audience) The beautiful concert that you just  heard could be the last concert of  the East Harlem Violin Program. The  Board of Education and the District  Superintendent don't think that music  is important for our children. But  they're wrong -- and they're in for  a fight.
The parents stand and applaud. We see the REPORTER writin quickly. Dorothea snaps more pictures. Roberta extends an arm towards the kids, directing the applause at them. Ram gives her a thumbs up.
ROBERTA is vacuuming the living room while Assunta dusts. Extra chairs are set up in the living room in preparation for a meeting. The doorbell RINGS.
Someone's early.

FOLLOW ASSUNTA to the DOOR. She opens it, revealing JANET who's carrying two bags of groceries. Assunta's demeanor  instantly cools when she sees her. In the b.g. Roberta se Janet and turns off the vacuum cleaner.
Hello, Assunta. How are you?
I'd be a lot better if my daughter  had a job next year.
Ma!
(to Assunta) I would too.
Janet briskly walks into THE LIVING ROOM, puts the grocer bags down on a table, and begins to take things out of th Roberta watches her, mystified.
(to Roberta) Sorry I'm early, but I figured we'd  need time to set up.
Roberta watches Janet for a beat, then addresses Assunta.
Mama, why don't you take Allegra out  for a walk?

Assunta hesitates for a beat, then gets the dog and exits Janet continues unpacking the bags as if there's nothing  unusual about her being there. Cheeses, crackers, bread,  salads, fruit, paper plates, napkins, etc. She sees Rober confused expression.
You are having a meeting here tonight,  right? Parents and teachers?
Well, yes, but ...
Take it from me. If you want to get  parents to help you with something,  you have to feed them.
She holds up two wedges of cheese.
You have a cutting board for these?
Roberta crosses into the kitchen and returns with a cutti board and a knife.
(as she continues to  unpack) And if you think parents are bad,  teachers are even worse, no offense.  If you don't feed them, you never  get anything extra out of them. That's  why I got this.
She pulls out an Entenmann's blackout cake.
Entenmann's gets them every time.
Roberta continues to stare in amazement at Janet.
What? Don't tell me you expected me  to bring something homemade.
(as she takes the  cake from her) Well, no... I --
Good. Because take it from me -- my  own family begs me to stay out of  the kitchen.
What I didn't expect was for you to  be here.

Why not? We've gotta figure out a  way to fight this. (as she arranges  crackers on a plate) After ten years, Roberta, I can't  imagine walking through those hallways  and not hearing that off-key,  screechy, scratchy, nails-on-the- blackboard violin music.
Roberta smiles. Janet holds up a baguette.
What do you think? Cut it into slices  now, or leave it whole?
Let's cut it now. It'll be less messy.
Janet hands her the bread. A beat as the two women exchan a private smile, then return to their respective tasks.

There's a crowd of PARENTS assembled in Roberta's front r talking at once, yelling out ideas, including CONCEPCION, BEVERLY WILSON (Shandra's mom), MR. ADAMS (Black) and MRS ADAMS (Puerto Rican), the parents of James (from Roberta' first year) and Simon. DOROTHEA, JANET, ISABEL are also t ASSUNTA is keeping tabs on the refreshments.
Don't they realize how much this  program helps the kids?
Simon's our third child to study  with Roberta. James is pre-med,  April's valedictorian -- now that  says something!
I think we should inundate the Board  and the District with letters.
You're wasting your time. The Board  and the District are not gonna pay  for this program, no matter how many  letters they get.
Disappointed grumblings.
What if we raise the money ourselves?
I can't see how they'd object to  that.
A beat as people take this in.
Well once that newspaper article  comes out, that should help bring in  money.
Yeah, but what if it doesn't? For  all we know, it's gonna be buried on  the back page. Besides, who says  anyone's gonna give a damn about our  kids?

(to Roberta) What if you do a benefit concert? We  can raise a batch of money from ticket  sales, and then the concert itself  could be great publicity. There's  word of mouth... you could get  reviewed...
It better be a good concert!
Some people laugh but we see the anxiety on Roberta's fac
We have to offer something more than  me and the kids. (to Dorothea) Do you think maybe your husband would  perform with us?
(slyly) I'm sure I could persuade him with a  little pillow talk. And maybe he can  get another violinist too -- Itzhak  Perlman, perhaps.
This gets people's attention.
That would be fantastic.
We could rent a place like the 92nd  Street Y -- it's perfect for this.  It seats about nine hundred people  and if we charge between fifty and a  hundred a ticket --
(to Roberta) We could probably raise enough to  reinstate your program for a year.
Sounds like a plan.
(half to herself) It better be a good concert.
The DOORBELL RINGS and Roberta crosses to get it. DAN ent holding copies of the NY POST, the DAILY NEWS, and a coup of other papers. Each paper has been opened to a specific page.
Take your pick.
Roberta grabs the top one -- the POST -- opened to page 5
The page has a photo of Roberta at the Spring Concert, an large article headlined A VIOLIN TEACHER FIGHTS BACK.
Lots of chaos as a TELEVISION NEWS CREW sets up. Roberta  tries futilely to get the beginners to pay attention to h
Kids, listen to me -- it's really  important that you don't look at the  camera and you try to act as natural  as possible.
Dennis storms in.
Who authorized this?
Janet.
Well Janet's not here today and I  want these people out of here.
The kids quiet down and watch them argue. A CAMERA GUY st shooting the argument and Dennis sees him.
Turn that off, you hear me?
Why are you doing this? We're not  bothering anyone.
You're disrupting school and I want  them out of here -- now.

You still don't get it, do you? I  don't care if you hate me, Dennis --  that's your business. But think about  the students for once. Every time  you interfere, you're not hurting me --  you're hurting them.
She points to the kids. They're silent, waiting to see if Roberta got through to him. A beat.
Get these people out of here or I'm  calling the police.
Go right ahead, call them. That'll  look real good on the eleven o'clock  news.
A beat and he exits. Roberta takes a deep breath, then tu back to the kids who are watching her, impressed.
I don't hear no sirens.
ON THE TV is the news segment: ROBERTA speaks to an unsee interviewer.
I'm from a blue collar family, and  if it weren't for the lessons I got  in public school, I never would have  learned the violin.
It CUTS TO Roberta's beginners speaking to the interviewe
How does it make you feel to lose  your violin program?
It makes us sad!
Yeah, like we're never gonna have no  more violin lessons --
And it's bad because... because we  love violin class.
WIDER - REVEAL Roberta, Lexi and Nick watching the TV.
Yes, I've gotten offers from two  private schools, but this is where I  want to be.
Arnold, these kids need help.
WIDER - REVEAL a comfortable Upper East Side apartment an DOROTHEA watching T.V. while ARNOLD practices violin. The FRAMED PHOTOGRAPHY on the walls, signed by Dorothea.
Didn't we send them a donation?
They need something bigger. And you  can't just write a check -- you have  to get involved.
Involved how?
The look on her face tells him it's more than he bargaine for.
Uh-oh.

1. Arnold Steinhardt speaks on the phone. His Roladex is  open to the name ITZHAK PERLMAN. In the b.g., Dorothea te waits to hear if Itzhak Perlman will say yes. 2. Parents, Roberta, Nick and Lexi hang "FIDDLEFEST CONCE posters around their neighborhood, announcing a concert a THE 92ND STREET Y with ARNOLD STEINHARDT, ITZHAK PERLMAN STUDENTS FROM THE EAST HARLEM VIOLIN PROGRAM. 3. Parents -- including Beverly Wilson, Concepcion, Mr. A and Carlos' mom and dad -- stuff envelopes with INVITATIO to "FIDDLEFEST" and accompanying LETTERS and TICKET ORDER FORMS. Roberta and Dorothea open envelopes with filled-ou TICKET ORDER FORMS and CHECKS. They stack the checks in a pile, address return envelopes and place FIDDLEFEST TICKE inside them.

Thirty-three excited kids from Roberta's different classe chat, tune their violins, rosin their bows. The students  include Carlos, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, Rachel, Simon,  Ramon, Vanessa, and Shandra. Roberta enters the room, ful of energy, and addresses them as she heads to the front.
Listen up, everyone! Quiet down!
The students give her their attention.

You are my very best beginner and  advanced violin students and I've  chosen you to play in Fiddlefest  because I trust that you can handle  the pressure. It's gonna be a lot of  work -- a lot. Right now, we've sold  some tickets, but I'm not gonna be  back here in the fall if the audience  storms out of their seats, demanding  a refund!
She nods to Rachel who starts handing out sheets of music
Rachel's gonna be my lieutenant and  I expect you to listen to her.
Ramon looks through his music sheets.
Bach's "Minuet One"?
People are gonna be paying good money  for this concert -- we're not just  gonna play "Twinkle." (handing out papers) I'm passing out a contract that you  and your parents need to sign.
The kids read the contracts. Carlos' eyes widen.
Every Saturday and Sunday?
Plus night time rehearsals during  the week. There's only six weeks  till the concert, so classes in school  won't be enough.
The kids look sobered by this.
Come to think of it, we'll probably  also need to meet before school.
Lots of grumbling: "Say what?" "No way!" "Before school?" I'ma be sleepwalking!"
You've heard of Navy Seal Training?  Well, this is gonna be Roberta String  Training.

ANOTHER ANGLE - Two young men and two young women walk in carrying violins. We realize from the scar that one is NA (20), now a strikingly handsome man, over six feet tall.  With him is DE SEAN (19), a short guy with dreadlocks, lo more like a rapper than a violinist. GUADALUPE (19), walk with a cane, is now a beautiful young woman, her long bra pinned up. The fourth is a reserved Puerto Rican woman (2
Oh my god! Naeem! De Sean! (hugs them) Guadalupe!
She hugs her, then looks closely at the other woman.
Lucy? Is that you?
The woman snaps her fingers and smiles. Roberta laughs an embraces her, then turns to the students.
Kids, these are four of my very first  violin students and I've asked them  to play in the concert with us. (to the alumni) I was just telling them how hard  they're gonna have to work.
(to class) Take it from me -- this lady don't  lie. Y'all are gonna work your butts  off.

Ramon's father carefully reads the violin contract while  Ramon and Concepcion anxiously watch. He stops to look up word in the English-Spanish dictionary beside him. Ramon his mom are squirming. Manuelo nods as he finishes readin then SIGNS the contract. Ramon breaks into a smile, throw his little arms around his Papa and kisses him.

School's letting out; Carlos' sister exits, carrying Carl violin. A few beats later, Carlos quickly exits, checking his watch. He sees his LOS LEONES teammates standing in a group, and tries to bypass them without being noticed, bu they spot him.
Hey Carlos! Where ya goin'? We got a  game, remember?
Yeah, I know, but... I can't make  it.
What you talkin' about?
I just can't make it.
You got a date with the violin  teacher?
A beat.
Yeah. I do.
He dashes off, a barrage of Spanish and English curses be him, and crosses to his sister, waiting for him DOWN THE  STREET. He takes the violin from her and carries it himse

The Fiddlefest kids, including Carlos, Vanessa, Shandra,  Ramon, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, Simon, Thomas, De Sean a Guadalupe practice Bach's "Minuet One," Roberta leading t and giving direction. They're playing badly. Rachel plays as well, but walks around the room making  corrections. It's early morning, and the kids look half- asleep.
Frog! Frog! I need more accents on  the down beat! More bow! More!
They play a few more bars and still sound pretty bad.
Stop! Stop! (they do so) You sound horrible! Isn't anyone  practicing?
How can we practice? We're rehearsing  all the time.
Some kids laugh, including Stephanie.

(to Stephanie) You think this is funny, Stephanie? (to all of them) You think the four hundred people  who've bought tickets so far will  think it's funny too? You think Itzhak  Perlman will think it's funny that  he's donating his time and you're  all gonna stink?
Vanessa yawns and Roberta sees her. Uh-oh.
Am I boring you, Vanessa?
No. It's 7:30 in the morning. I'm  just tired.
There's no time to be tired. (to all, getting her  violin in position) Let's try it again.
Dorothea opens the door for Roberta who just charges in,  agitated, without even saying hello. We sense that Doroth too, is troubled by something.

I must have been crazy to agree to  this. They're never gonna be ready.  And you should hear the Bach Double!  A disaster. So the good news is  tickets are selling like hot cakes,  but the bad news is that the kids  sound like shit.
There's more bad news... We've lost  the Y.
Roberta looks at her, aghast.
What?!
They had a flood -- a water heater  burst... The concert hall was damaged  and they've cancelled all events.
Until when?
"Until further notice."
This can't happen! We've sold tickets!  We've done publicity! The concert's  in three weeks!
I've been on the phone all morning  calling other theaters. Nothing's  available.
They both sink into the couch, completely undone by this.
Just keep looking.

The Fiddlefest kids are crammed into Roberta's house,  (including De Sean, Guadalupe, Ramon, Vanessa, Shandra,  Carlos, Thomas, Stephanie, Amanda, Kenny, and Simon),  rehearsing "Orange Blossom Special." They play badly. Rac helps Roberta correct students.
Stop! Someone's playing the wrong  notes! And you shouldn't need your  music anymore! Except for the Bach  Double, everything has to be memorized  by next rehearsal!
The kids look at each other, daunted.
And you sound like you're  sleepwalking. Your heart's not even  in it.
Maybe 'cause we don't have a place  for the concert.
Roberta looks at her, and then notices the despondent loo on many of the kids' faces.
Well, you're right. This might all  be for nothing. So we can either  keep on rehearsing in case we find a  place -- or we can just... give up.
Am I hearing right? Did you use the  words "give up"? (to the students) Let's take a vote. How many of you  want to give up?
No one raises a hand. Roberta takes this in.
See? You taught us well.
It's early morning. Lexi cooks breakfast while Nick and  Roberta look at scribbled-on, marked-up lists.
What about in the Bronx?
There's nothing. (beat) Why don't you just do it in one of  the schools? It'll be a lot smaller  but --
We won't make enough money.
What about postponing it?
Itzhak and Arnold are booked all  summer.
They all look depressed. Lexi places an equally depressin looking stack of pancakes on the table. There's a BANGING the door, startling everyone.
It's Dorothea.
Nick opens the door and Dorothea rushes in, out of breath talking a mile a minute.

I have good news -- really good news.  Arnold got a call from his friend  Wally Scheur who heard about us losing  the Y and wanted to see how he could  help -- and then Wally had this  brilliant idea and called his friend  Isaac Stern and it's all arranged!  We have a new place for Fiddlefest!
Where?
Carnegie Hall.
Dorothea grins from ear to ear, Nick and Lexi whoop and  holler, and all wait for Roberta to jump up and down for but she looks stricken.
(panicked) Carnegie Hall?
CLOSE ON THE CEILING OF CARNEGIE HALL, revolving slowly.

She stands on the empty stage, gazing at the ceiling as s slowly turns around. She's holding her violin case. She l at the UPPER BALCONIES -- THE LOWER BALCONIES -- THE ORCH SEATS. Her footsteps echo as she walks towards the front the stage, then stops.

We can see her imagining the audience on the night of the concert. She can't believe her eyes. A beat, and she look around to make sure she's alone. She takes out her violin takes a deep breath as she looks out towards her "audienc then starts to play the second violin part of the Bach Do Concerto. Suddenly, there's the SOUND of a stage door ope Roberta stops.
Incredible sound in this room, no?
Roberta turns to see ISAAC STERN approaching her. She's  completely flustered.
Oh my god -- Isaac Stern.
You must be Roberta.
Thank you so much for helping us.
(looking out at the  hall) Would you believe in 1960, they tried  to tear this place down? They wanted  to replace it with a bright red  skyscraper -- we called it "the red  terror."
You're kidding.
We had to fight like hell, but with  a lot of help, we saved Carnegie  Hall.
Roberta takes this in, relating it to her own struggle.
If it's all right with you, I'd like  to play in your concert. Maybe bring  a couple of friends...
Yes, of course! That would be great!
Isaac nods, then touches her shoulder.
Don't give up.
Roberta pours nervous energy into her cappuccino, adding  cinnamon, chocolate, and sugar, stirring loudly. Dan sits across from her, observing.

I just don't see how I'm gonna do  this. It's huge. It's gigantic! It's  Carnegie Hall! And listen to this:  now Isaac Stern wants to play with  us -- Diane Monroe, Michael Tree --  there's other people calling --
That's fantastic!
Fantastic? I'll never get the kids  up to speed in time, I'll never get  myself up to speed. I'm gonna be  playing side by side with the world's  greatest violinists.
And "the world's greatest violinists"  are playing side by side with you  because they want to help you win  this fight.
He offers her a forkful of some decadent-looking chocolat cake, but she shakes her head.

Yes, but... you don't understand.  Maybe there's a good reason why I  never made it as a violinist -- maybe  I just can't cut it. I keep blaming  it on not having enough early  training, but if I were talented, if  I had a gift --

But you do have a gift. You're gonna  put thirty East Harlem kids on stage  at Carnegie Hall not because they're  prodigies, but because you got them  to stick with something that's hard  as hell and to strive for excellence --  which, by the way, I certainly wasn't  striving for when I was their age.  Not to mention the other ten years'  worth of students whose lives were  changed because of you. That's your  talent, Roberta.
She takes this in, looks at him gratefully and puts her h over his. He strokes her hand.
I'm scared.
I know. (beat) And by the way, I happen to think  you're a pretty good violinist too.
You've barely heard me play.
I've heard enough to know you're  gonna do just fine.
Roberta looks at him with trepidation. Dan takes another  forkful of his cake.
Besides, no one's gonna be paying  attention to your playing anyway.
Roberta laughs. Dan smiles, glad he got her to lighten up

The Fiddlefest kids (including Ramon, Shandra, Vanessa, D Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Simon, Stephanie, Amanda an Kenny -- but RACHEL is absent) stand outside the locked s gate, waiting for Roberta. Some of the kids have their vi out of the cases, tuning them.
Teacher's late. I think she should  be dropped, don't you?
Kids laugh.
Yeah. I don't think we should let  her play in Fiddlefest!

A few kids start playing "CAN-CAN." It catches on, and mo of them join in. PASSERSBY stop to listen, and some drop  change into the open cases. RAMON and a couple of other k grin at this. CARLOS steps in front of the kids as he plays, and begins uncanny imitation of Roberta:
More bow! To the frog! You sound  terrible! I can't believe how terrible  you sound!
The kids crack up, but a few spot ROBERTA heading quickly the street. Carlos is oblivious to this -- and no one sig him that Roberta's watching.
You're gonna make everyone in Carnegie  Hall sick to their stomachs! That's  right, they're gonna pay a thousand  dollars a ticket and you're gonna  make them throw up on their gowns  and tuxedos!
Carlos senses a presence and turns to see Roberta. A tens beat as he awaits her reaction.
(in all seriousness) If you're gonna imitate me, do it  right. (corrects his posture) Shoulders back. Violin higher. Check  your feet. There. (beat) G'head, Carlos. Continue.
Carlos freezes.
No, that's O.K. You can take it from  here.
Roberta nods, and addresses the kids as she unlocks the g
He's right, by the way. You do sound  terrible, and you are gonna make  everyone in Carnegie Hall sick to  their stomachs.
The kids start filing in. Rachel comes up the street and  catches up to Roberta.
I need to talk to you.
Roberta sees how distressed Rachel looks.
(to kids) I'll be right in. Start on Minuet  One. (to Rachel) What's wrong?
We're moving away.
What? Where are you moving?
(looking downward) It's a secret... My father... he's  been hurting my mom... We have to  leave.
(gently) Has he been hurting you too?
Rachel shakes her head no, then starts to cry a little.
I'm sorry about Julliard... and the  concert.
She hands Roberta her violin.
Keep it. Take it with you.
No... I don't want to play anymore.
What?! You can't give up violin,  Rachel -- it's a part of you. A very  important part.
Rachel looks anguished. Roberta moves closer and touches arm.
Please honey. Just take it.
I don't want to.
Roberta looks at her, pained, then hugs her. Rachel quick kisses Roberta goodbye and exits. Roberta watches her.

Roberta leads De Sean, Naeem, Guadalupe, Lucy, Stephanie, Thomas, Carlos, Erica and Nicholas in the Bach Double  Concerto. The other kids watch. Roberta's on the edge of  hysteria. She signals the players to stop.

No, no, no! Accent the up bow after  the slurred notes and then it'll get  you off of those slurred notes! You  Double Concerto kids need to be  working harder! This is the grand  finale of the concert! You're each  gonna be sharing a music stand with  one of the world's greatest  violinists!
The kids say "the world's greatest violinists" along with her -- they've obviously been hearing this a lot. Roberta glares at them.

O.K... (not believing it) It's gonna be O.K.

When I became the principal of Central  Park East Elementary, I envisioned a  school where children could fulfill  their highest potential, despite the  challenges of poverty and racism.  Ten years ago, Roberta Guaspari walked  into my office because she needed a  job, and because she had a vision  that any child could learn the violin.  We put our dreams together and created  the East Harlem Violin Program which  has helped more than a thousand  students expand their vision of what's  possible in their lives. When a  program like this is cut, our  children's future is compromised. I  want to thank you for your support.  Enjoy the concert.
In the b.g. we hear the audience APPLAUDING Janet. Robert holds up her hands to quiet down the anxious students.
Everyone -- attention please!
They become quiet.
I want you all to take a second just  to breathe, O.K.? Deep breath.
The kids breathe.

I would like you all to play with  your heart, all right? Play like I  know you can play. You'll be  wonderful. Watch me, don't look out  in the audience -- you don't need to  be afraid. It's gonna be really  wonderful. So play -- play from here.
She pats her heart.
The kids head out towards the stage, the APPLAUSE getting louder as they get closer.

Roberta Guaspari lives in East Harlem with her daughter S whom she adopted from El Salvador. Nick is a professional cellist in a graduate music program, and Alexi has been  accepted to medical school. Roberta teaches violin to approximately 150 students a ye in three East Harlem elementary schools. The East Harlem  Violin Program, however, is still not funded by the New Y City Board of Education. The money raised from Fiddlefest supported Roberta's viol program for three years. Roberta and Opus 118 continue th fundraising efforts to keep the program alive.
